A 52-year-old man comes to the physician with leg ulcers. Two months ago a small ulcer appeared on the right medial malleolus, and now there are 2 additional ulcers on both legs. He was diagnosed with seropositive rheumatoid arthritis 15 years ago and has been on oral prednisone, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine since then. Eight years ago methotrexate was discontinued due to liver toxicity. Five years ago he received etanercept for a few months, but this was discontinued due to frequent sinus infections.

The patient's other medical problems include gastritis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and colon polyps. He is a cattle farmer and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.

He is afebrile and vital signs are normal. Skin examination is notable for several nodules on the extensor surface of the elbows. There are 3 shallow ulcers on both legs in various stages of healing. Heart and lung sounds are normal. Spleen is palpable 2 cm below the left costal margin. There are rheumatoid deformities of both hands and feet with decreased range of motion in wrists, elbows, and ankle joints. Neurologic examination is normal.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 84 fL
Platelets: 148,000/μL
Leukocytes: 3,300/μL
Neutrophils: 30%
Lymphocytes: 70%
Serum chemistry
Sodium: 140 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
Calcium: 9.4 mg/dL
Glucose: 100 mg/dL
Liver function studies
Total protein: 6.5 g/dL
Albumin: 3.7 g/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 70 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 37 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 24 U/L
Immunologic and rheumatologic studies
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 92 mm/h
explanation:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and splenomegaly, a triad known as Felty's syndrome (FS). It occurs in about 1% of patients with seropositive, advanced rheumatoid arthritis (usually > 10 years). Almost all patients have positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies. Patients can develop extra-articular manifestations such as mononeuritis multiplex, necrotizing skin lesions, pleuropericarditis, lymphadenopathy, and episcleritis. Patients are at increased risk for skin and respiratory tract infections due to neutropenia. Diagnosis requires bone marrow biopsy to rule out other causes of neutropenia, such as large granular lymphocyte syndrome. Treatment of FS is methotrexate and other disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs. Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor can be given to patients with life-threatening or refractory infections.

(Choice A) Absence of renal manifestations and the presence of splenomegaly make polyarteritis nodosa unlikely.

(Choice C) Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a chronic, inflammatory skin condition most commonly seen in diabetics. The lesions typically appear as indurated plaques with central atrophy and yellow-brown pigmentation.

(Choice D) Pyoderma gangrenosum is a skin condition frequently associated with systemic disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease. Patients present with painful, necrotic skin ulcerations. Pyoderma gangrenosum is not associated with splenomegaly.

(Choice E) Sweet's syndrome is neutrophilic dermatoses associated with malignancy and autoimmune diseases (eg, inflammatory bowel disease). It presents with abrupt onset of erythematous plaques with pseudoblistering and pustules on the face, neck, chest, and extremities. It is frequently preceded by flu-like symptoms, and laboratory results show leukocytosis (not present in this patient).

stem:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the office with 3 months of right foot pain. Her symptoms started with nighttime numbness at the bottom of the right foot that has progressed to burning and aching pain. She also has vague discomfort while standing or sitting, especially when wearing shoes. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, which has been stable with weekly etanercept and as-needed ibuprofen. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.

Examination shows swollen hand joints without tenderness and mild radial deviation of the wrist. She has mild hallux valgus deformity without focal tenderness on foot examination. Light tapping behind the right medial malleolus elicits tingling. There is intact sensation to light touch and vibration.
explanation:
This patient's clinical features suggest tarsal tunnel syndrome, which is due to posterior tibial nerve compression as it passes under the flexor retinaculum posterior to the medial malleolus. Tarsal tunnel syndrome is most common following an ankle fracture or dislocation involving the talus, calcaneus, or medial malleolus, in which scar tissue, bony spurs, or bone/cartilage fragments can compress the nerve. Other etiologies include malignancy or inflammatory conditions (eg, rheumatoid arthritis). Patients usually develop pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the nerve (sole of the foot, distal foot, or toes). The pain can radiate up to the heel and calf and is worse at night or with standing. Taking off shoes often relieves the discomfort. Examination can show a positive Tinel's sign (tingling sensation on light percussion over the nerve) and/or sensory loss. Severe nerve injury can lead to atrophy of intrinsic foot muscles. Diagnosis is mainly clinical, although electrodiagnostic testing may be helpful. Treatment includes anti-inflammatory medications (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), shoe modification, or corticosteroid injection, with decompressive surgery in refractory cases.

(Choice A) Drug-induced neuropathy typically presents with significant bilateral sensory abnormalities and motor weakness. This patient's unilateral presentation and intact sensory examination make this less likely.

(Choice B) Morton neuroma presents with numbness or pain between the third and fourth toes and a clicking sensation (Mulder sign) that occurs when simultaneously palpating this space and squeezing the metatarsal joints. Tinel's sign is not a characteristic of Morton neuroma.

(Choice C) Plantar fasciitis causes pain and focal tenderness in the plantar area of the rearfoot. The pain may be severe with the first steps of the day. It then often decreases with activity only to worsen again later in the day with prolonged weight bearing.

(Choice D) Stress fractures are due to repeated tension or compression without adequate rest that eventually breaks the bone. Patients typically present with sharp and localized pain over a bony surface that is worse with palpation.

stem:
A 35-year-old man is evaluated for pain and swelling behind his right foot that is exacerbated by walking. He reports chronic back pain that occurs mostly in the morning and at night. The pain improves during the day and with exercise, but not with rest. He takes over-the-counter ibuprofen with significant back pain relief. The patient has no fatigue, headaches, vision problems, or abdominal complaints. He has no other medical problems. His mother suffers from rheumatoid arthritis.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 13.0 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 88 fL
C-reactive protein (CRP): 25 mg/L
explanation:
This patient's presentation suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Ankylosing spondylitis usually presents in adults age < 40 with chronic low back pain due to sacroiliitis. The pain occurs during the day and night and tends to improve with exercise, but not with rest. Patients usually develop enthesitis at insertion sites of tendons to bone (eg, Achilles tendon, plantar fascia, shoulder), limited spinal mobility or chest wall expansion, and possible extra-articular manifestations (eg, anterior uveitis, osteopenia with increased fracture risk). Limited chest wall expansion is due to costovertebral rigidity. Normal chest wall expansion is 5 cm after maximum forced expiration followed by maximum inspiration. Expansion < 2.5 cm is considered abnormal and suggests AS. Patients with kyphoscoliosis and deformity above T10 are at increased risk for nocturnal hypoventilation and apneic events as well as respiratory failure. Advanced AS may have x-ray findings of continuous fusion of the lumbar spine ("bamboo spine"). Treatment of respiratory impairment includes pulmonary rehabilitation and noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation.

(Choice A) Marfan syndrome usually presents with increased arm span to height ratio and is associated with aortic root dilatation/dissection, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and pneumothorax.

(Choice C) The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is a diagnostic test to identify benign paroxysmal positional vertigo. In the presence of posterior canal dysfunction, the maneuver generally provokes vertigo and nystagmus.

(Choice D) The drop arm test is used to assess the integrity of the supraspinatus tendon for rotator cuff injuries. A positive test occurs when the patient is unable to lower the affected arm from a fully abducted position in a smooth, controlled manner compared to the unaffected arm.

(Choice E) The Romberg test is used to test proprioception (dorsal columns of the spinal cord). Causes of a positive test include cervical spondylotic myelopathy, B12 deficiency, and neurosyphilis.

stem:
A 33-year-old woman comes to the office due to a 2-day history of severe left knee pain and swelling. She has had no trauma, pain in other joints, fever, chills, or rash. The patient has a history of parathyroid adenoma with primary hyperparathyroidism and underwent parathyroidectomy a week ago. Her other medical problems include moderate persistent asthma, irritable bowel syndrome, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She is married and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Temperature is 36.7 C (98F), blood pressure is 110/56 mm Hg, pulse is 67/min, and respirations are 14/min. BMI is 28 kg/m2. Physical examination shows a moderate left knee effusion with warmth, erythema, and tenderness. Range of motion of the knee is decreased due to pain.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Leukocytes: 9,600/mm3
Hemoglobin: 11.1 g/dL
Platelets: 350,000/mm3
Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 46 mm/hr
Analysis of synovial fluid from the knee joint shows a leukocyte count of 20,400/mm3 with 80% neutrophils.
explanation:
This patient has acute, inflammatory monoarticular arthritis affecting the knee. In light of her history of hyperparathyroidism and recent parathyroidectomy, this is most likely due to calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal arthritis (pseudogout). Hyperparathyroidism can lead to chondrocalcinosis in the articular cartilage; parathyroidectomy can precipitate a pseudogout attack due to an abrupt drop in serum calcium levels, which triggers crystal shedding into the synovial fluid. Pseudogout commonly affects the knees, where it may be difficult to distinguish from urate gout. It also frequently affects the wrists and ankles and may involve multiple joints concurrently. Attacks often occur in the setting of trauma/overuse, surgery, or medical illness. The primary treatment is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; intra-articular glucocorticoids and colchicine can also be considered.

(Choice A) Although gout can also present with monoarthritis, this patient has no risk factors for gout (eg, obesity, alcohol use), and her recent parathyroidectomy is more strongly associated with pseudogout.

(Choice B) Erosive osteoarthritis typically occurs in patients age >40. It presents with pain and stiffness. crepitus and tenderness on examination, joint space narrowing on x-rays, and clear synovial fluid with <2,000/mm3 white blood cells.

(Choice C) Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a rare complication of severe primary hyperparathyroidism characterized by subperiosteal bone resorption in the middle phalanges, tapering of the distal clavicles, "salt and pepper" appearance of the skull, bone cysts, and brown tumors of the long bones. Patients typically experience chronic bone pain rather than acute arthritis (as in this patient).

(Choice E) Septic arthritis typically presents with markedly decreased range of motion, increased warmth and swelling, and cloudy joint aspirate with >100.000/mm3 white blood cells (predominantly neutrophils).

A 20-year-old woman comes to the office due to atraumatic heel pain over the last week. For the past 6-8 months, the patient has also experienced bilateral hip pain that has progressively worsened and now awakens her during the early-morning hours. When this occurs, she gets up and walks around for a few minutes before going back to sleep. The patient also has difficulty tying her shoelaces in the morning due to back pain and stiffness; however, she does not feel limited when performing other daytime activities. She has tried over-the-counter pain medications and found ibuprofen to be more effective than acetaminophen. A year ago, she had an episode of intense pain, photophobia, and redness involving her left eye, which improved with corticosteroid eye drops. The patient also occasionally has mouth ulcers, usually around the time of her menstrual periods. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother and multiple sclerosis in her aunt. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. She is sexually active and uses oral contraceptives for birth control.

Vital signs are normal. The oral mucosa is moist with mild tonsillar swelling, but there are no ulcers or other lesions. There is tenderness and swelling of the heel, as shown in the exhibit. Examination of the ankle and other joints shows no synovitis or effusion. Flexion and external rotation of the hip joints elicits intense pain at the gluteal region.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Leukocytes: 5,600/mm3
Hemoglobin: 12.5 g/dL
Platelets: 320,000/mm3
C-reactive protein: 10 mg/L (normal: <8)
choice_b: Cervical swab culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae
explanation:
Enthesitis is characterized by swelling, tenderness, and pain at tendon insertion sites (eg, Achilles tendon at the heel, costosternal junction, shoulders, elbows, hips, iliac crests, tibial tuberosities). Enthesitis may occur as an isolated disorder (eg, plantar fasciitis) but is a characteristic finding in the spondyloarthropathies (eg, ankylosing spondylitis [AS], psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis). This patient has features suggesting AS, including enthesitis at the heel and hips, inflammatory back pain (ie, insidious onset, stiffness, worse in the morning/with rest), and possible uveitis. The incidence of AS is highest at age 20-30. Examination often shows decreases in chest expansion (<2 cm expansion with inspiration suggests AS), cervical extension, and lumbar flexion. Dactylitis and peripheral joint synovitis are also possible. An anteroposterior x-ray of the pelvis revealing arthritis and erosions of the sacroiliac joints can confirm the diagnosis in most patients. Inflammatory markers (eg, C-reactive protein) are commonly elevated. HLA-B27 is positive in most patients and correlates with aggressive disease. Initial treatment includes nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and range-of-motion exercises.

(Choice A) Enthesitis can occur in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, but synovitis is more common. In addition, this patient does not have more characteristic findings of lupus (eg, malar rash, anemia); therefore, anti-double-stranded DNA antibody testing is not indicated.

(Choice B) Disseminated gonococcal infection presents as purulent monoarthritis or a triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis, and migratory polyarthralgias. Reactive arthritis is a spondyloarthropathy that resembles AS with inflammatory back pain, enthesitis, and peripheral arthritis but more commonly follows nongonococcal (eg, Chlamydia trachomatis) rather than gonococcal urethritis.

(Choice C) Sarcoidosis can cause uveitis and arthritis of the ankle and knee joints, but enthesitis and inflammatory back pain are uncommon. Chest x-ray to evaluate for hilar adenopathy is not needed.

(Choice D) Pathergy testing (formation of an inflammatory papule following insertion of a sterile needle into the skin) is useful for diagnosing Behçet disease. This disorder causes aphthous ulcers, uveitis, and genital ulcers but does not typically cause inflammatory back pain. Aphthous ulcers are a common, nonspecific finding often seen in association with menstrual periods and/or stress.

A 55-year-old man comes to the physician due to myalgias, arthralgias, and weight loss. He has not felt well for 2 years. Over that time, he has experienced 4 episodes of sinusitis that responded poorly to treatment and required prolonged courses of antibiotics for symptom resolution. During the last 6 months, the patient has experienced diffuse aches. He has pain that migrates from his knees to his shoulders and wrists and has also lost 4.5 kg (10 lb). He has no history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or chronic kidney disease.

His blood pressure is 138/90 mm Hg. A small amount of crusted blood is present in one nostril. There are no other significant physical findings.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 12.6 g/dL
Hematocrit: 36%
Platelets: 410,000/mm3
Leukocytes: 9,900/mm3
Serum chemistry
Sodium: 142 mEq/L
Potassium: 4.4 mEq/L
Chloride: 98 mEq/L
Bicarbonate: 24 mEq/L
Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
Urinalysis
Specific gravity: 1.016
Protein: +2
Blood: Moderate
Red blood cells: 20-30/hpf
Casts: Coarsely granular casts

Chest CT reveals two 2-3 cm nodules in the left upper lobe. Serum anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are negative.
explanation:
This patient most likely has granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly called Wegener's granulomatosis. Prompt diagnosis and institution of therapy may be kidney- and life-sparing. GPA is suspected in patients with 22 of the following: nasal or oral inflammation, abnormal chest radiograph, abnormal urinary sediment, and granulomatous inflammation on biopsy of an artery or perivascular area. Pathogenesis involves anti-neutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) reacting with 1 of 2 proteins (serine proteinase 3 or myeloperoxidase) on the surface of cytokine-stimulated white blood cells. Although up to 90% of patients with generalized GPA have positive ANCA, negative ANCA does not rule out the diagnosis. Tissue biopsy is typically obtained at the site of active disease (eg, skin, kidney, lung) to make a definitive diagnosis. This patient has evidence of renal disease with active urinary sediment; therefore, kidney biopsy should be obtained and may show pauci-immune segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis with few or no immune deposits on electron microscopy. Lung biopsy can be obtained in patients with predominant lung disease; however, this often requires open or thoracoscopic biopsy as transbronchial biopsy generally does not yield a sufficient quantity of tissue (Choice B). The diagnostic yield of nasal biopsy is also very low due to the small amount of tissue obtained (Choice D). Therapy should be started in patients with suspected GPA if there is a delay in obtaining tissue biopsy, regardless of the ANCA result.

(Choice A) Infective endocarditis can have a similar presentation, especially if it is right-sided given the lung lesions. However, this patient's 6-month history of multiple, refractory sinus infections makes this diagnosis unlikely.

(Choice E) Urine eosinophils are seen in acute interstitial nephritis, which is rarely associated with GPA. In addition, this patient has no rash or history of recent exposure to triggering medications.

A 35-year-old immigrant from Eastern Europe comes to the office due to dry cough, malaise, and fatigue. He has had joint aches and involuntary weight loss over the past 3 months. His other medical problems include severe allergies that manifest as nasal stuffiness, headache, and ear pain. He takes over-the- counter decongestants. He is a construction worker, smokes a pack of cigarettes a day, and drinks 6 cans of beer once a week. His mother suffers from severe rheumatoid arthritis.

His temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 89/min. He has tenderness on palpation of bilateral maxillary sinuses. Tympanic membranes are full and bulging bilaterally. Pulmonary auscultation reveals occasional rhonchi. There are no heart murmurs. The tip of the spleen is not palpable. There are no skin rashes or joint swelling.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL
Leukocytes: 5,500/mm3
Platelets: 710,000/mm3
Potassium: 4.5 mEq/L
Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL

Liver panel is unremarkable. Urinalysis is positive for blood and protein, and urine sediment analysis reveals multiple red blood cells casts. Chest x-ray is shown below.
explanation:
This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with a systemic vasculitis. The history of weight loss, arthralgias, anemia of chronic disease, ear/sinus symptoms, pulmonary nodules, and renal insufficiency with glomerulonephritis suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly Wegener granulomatosis. It is an anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)-associated vasculitis, with nearly 90% of patients testing ANCA positive. However, the absence of ANCA does not exclude GPA. Immunofluorescence test results are reported as c-ANCA (cytoplasmic pattern) or p-ANCA (perinuclear pattern) titers. The c-ANCA pattern is caused by anti-proteinase 3 (PR3) antibodies, and the p-ANCA pattern is caused by anti-myeloperoxidase (MPO) antibodies. The c-ANCA pattern and anti-PR3 antibodies are most commonly associated with GPA; P-ANCA pattern and MPO are associated with microscopic polyangiitis (Choice B). However, patients with typical clinical presentation and tissue biopsy confirming vasculitis can be diagnosed with GPA, even with positive p-ANCA or negative ANCA.

(Choice A) Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are more specific for the diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus. However, this patient does not have other clinical criteria (eg, malar rash, photosensitivity, or pleurisy) for this disease. In addition, the pulmonary nodules and sinus/ear disease are more common with GPA.

(Choice D) Bone marrow biopsy would be indicated to evaluate for thrombocytosis due to myeloproliferative disorders. However, this patient likely has reactive thrombocytosis from vasculitis and does not have significant white blood cell or red blood cell abnormalities to warrant a biopsy.

(Choice E) Tuberculin skin testing may be indicated for this patient's pulmonary symptoms combined with weight loss. However, the renal involvement with active urinary sediment makes tuberculosis less likely.

stem:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician with the complaint of cold hands. Symptoms occur during winter months or when she reaches into the freezer at home. The coldness is often associated with intense pallor and a bluish color. On recovery, the hands feel warm and appear red and flushed. With severe attacks, the patient has numbness and tingling in the hands. On rare occasions, she can also feel the sensation in her toes. She denies skin rashes, joint pain, acid reflux, dyspnea, or chest pain. She has no other medical problems and takes no medication. Family history is unremarkable. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.

Her blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. Lungs are clear on auscultation. No bruits are heard in the periumbilical area. Peripheral pulses are symmetric and full. Skin examination is normal.
explanation:
This patient's presentation suggests primary Raynaud's phenomenon (RP). Patients usually experience biphasic color changes in the digits with thumb sparing during stress or on exposure to cold temperatures. Primary RP usually occurs in healthy women < age 30 without signs of tissue injury or abnormal laboratory findings (eg, ANA and ESR). Secondary RP is usually seen in men > age 40 and presents with signs of tissue ischemia or ulceration, abnormal laboratory findings, and/or systemic symptoms. Thumb involvement is also more common in secondary RP. Nailfold capillary examination can help differentiate between primary and secondary RP. It involves placing oil on the nailfold/cuticle and observing the capillaries with an ophthalmoscope. Normal capillaries are fine loops, and abnormal ones are enlarged with disorganized architecture and microhemorrhages. Normal nailfold capillaroscopy suggests primary RP, which has a low risk for subsequent development of connective tissue disease. Abnormal nailfold capillary structure suggests secondary RP, and the patient should be evaluated for an underlying disorder.

(Choice A) Ankle brachial index is performed to diagnose peripheral artery disease in patients with symptoms of claudication. However, this patient has symptoms during cold temperatures rather than with exertion.

(Choice B) This patient's absence of focal neurologic symptoms (eg, extremity weakness) makes TIA or stroke unlikely, and carotid duplex ultrasound would not be helpful.

(Choice C) This patient has no visual complaints, and dilated funduscopic eye examination would not be helpful.

(Choice D) Monofilament testing detects pressure sensation in an extremity and can predict the risk of developing neuropathy, ulcers, or amputation in diabetic patients. Although this patient has hand numbness, the symptoms occur with exposure to cold temperature and are not in the typical stocking-and- glove distribution seen in diabetic neuropathy.

stem: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician with a rash on her face for the past 4 weeks. The rash seems to get worse when she spends time outdoors, but it does not flare with food intake. She has no flushing or itching. The patient denies fever, weight loss, or muscle weakness. She was recently diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus and started on lisinopril, metformin, and sitagliptin. Physical examination reveals a 1-cm ulcer in the roof of the hard palate. A photograph of the rash is shown below.
explanation:
This patient presents with an acute photosensitive rash, oral ulcer, and new-onset hypertension, features suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Patients with SLE may present with rash months to years before development of other symptoms. The classic butterfly rash appears as erythema and scaling over the cheeks and bridge of nose with sparing of the nasolabial folds. It usually worsens with ultraviolet light exposure and can be mistaken for sunburn. Some patients may also have oral or nasopharyngeal ulcers, alopecia, or cutaneous bullae. Patients should be advised to avoid ultraviolet light exposure and use sun protection. Lupus rash can be treated initially with topical glucocorticoids, but patients with persistent rash should be treated with oral hydroxychloroquine (antimalarials). Systemic glucocorticoids and immunosuppressive agents are not used frequently except in patients with bullous lesions.

(Choice A) Typical lesions of erythema multiforme appear as target lesions with central erosions or bullae. Erythema multiforme occurs most commonly in the setting of an infection (eg, herpes simplex), and the lesions usually resolve within 2 weeks.

(Choice B) Patients with erythematotelangiectatic rosacea usually present with persistent facial erythema, telangiectasias, and episodes of facial flushing. They do not have the classic malar rash with abrupt cutoff (butterfly wing) that is seen in patients with lupus.

(Choice C) Drug eruptions usually begin within days to weeks of starting a new medication. They occur in dependent areas with subsequent generalization and are almost always pruritic.

(Choice D) Seborrheic dermatitis is characterized by scaling and erythema, usually on the scalp, face, and upper trunk (areas rich in sebaceous glands). When present on the face, it affects the lateral sides of the nose and nasolabial folds (unlike lupus), eyebrows, and forehead.

stem: A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to right knee pain over the last 2 weeks. The patient recently started running to lose weight and runs approximately 15 miles a week. He has since developed inner right knee pain, making it difficult to climb stairs. The pain is most intense at night when he is trying to fall asleep. Medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. The patient's temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 75/min. His BMI is 31 kg/m2 There is no knee swelling. Localized tenderness is noted at the medial aspect of the right knee, 1 inch below the joint line. While stabilizing the right thigh, lateral movement of the lower right leg elicits no knee pain or medial joint space movement. His gait is normal. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.
choice_a: Activity restriction, knee protection, and ice
choice_b: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and rheumatoid factor tests
explanation:
This patient with medial knee pain and focal tenderness has pes anserinus pain syndrome (PAPS). This condition is often referred to as anserine bursitis, but most patients do not have true inflammation in the bursa, and multiple regional structures can contribute to the pain. The pes anserinus is formed by the conjoined tendons of gracilis, sartorius, and semitendinosus. The anserine bursa is located anteromedially over the tibial plateau, just below the joint line of the knee and deep to the pes anserinus. PAPS can arise due to medial compartment knee osteoarthritis, trauma, or increased mechanical stress on the knee (eg, running, obesity). Localized pain is typical over the anteromedial tibia and is often exacerbated by pressure from the opposite knee while lying on the side. Examination shows a well-defined area of tenderness over the medial tibial plateau just below the joint line. The diagnosis is primarily based on clinical features. Acute therapy includes avoidance of leg crossing, limiting repetitive knee bending, decreasing pressure on the area by placing a pillow between the knees at night, and applying ice to reduce pain. Nonsteroidal anti- inflammatory drugs are often given for pain relief but may not be beneficial as oral medications do not concentrate well in the isolated anserine bursa.

(Choice B) The erythrocyte sedimentation rate and rheumatoid factor would be elevated in rheumatoid arthritis, which usually presents as polyarthritis rather than monoarthritis.

(Choice C) Glucocorticoid injections into the bursa are reserved for patients who fail conservative measures and have persistent symptoms for 6-8 weeks.

(Choice D) An MRI is often performed to assess the integrity of the medial collateral and associated ligaments when injury is suspected. However, this patient's negative valgus stress test makes this unlikely.

(Choice E) X-rays are not required to diagnose PAPS. They may identify medial compartment osteoarthritis, which can also contribute to medial knee pain; however, osteoarthritis is unlikely in this young patient without previous symptoms.

stem: A 78-year-old woman comes to the physician with a red and swollen right foot for the last 2 weeks. She also reports mild pain that is relieved with acetaminophen. There is no associated fever, chills, or morning stiffness. She has not fallen or had trauma to the foot. The patient's other medical problems include coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy and chronic kidney disease. Her medications include aspirin, lisinopril, metoprolol, insulin, and gabapentin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her body mass index is 32 kg/m2. Examination shows warmth, erythema, and edema to the plantar surface of the right foot. There is a visible collapse of the arch of the right mid-foot. No skin ulcers or sinus tracts are present. X-ray reveals advanced degenerative changes with dislocation of the mid-foot. Fluid aspiration from the right tarsus shows 200/mm3 red blood cells and 200/mm3 white blood cells (60% neutrophils). No crystals are seen and the Gram stain is negative.
choice_a: Casting with avoidance of weight bearing
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with acute diabetic neuropathic arthropathy, known as Charcot joint. Charcot joint is progressive bony and soft-tissue destruction leading to joint dislocation, incapacitating deformities, and instability. It is more common in diabetics likely due to neuropathy and vasculopathy but can occur in other conditions (eg, syphilis, chronic alcoholism). The presentation can mimic inflammatory or septic arthritis, with erythema, warmth, and edema to the foot and ankle. These conditions should be ruled out with joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis, as in this patient. Acute treatment involves casting and avoiding weight bearing until clinical findings resolve and x-ray findings improve. The cast is usually changed after 1-2 weeks to allow for resolving edema. Patients usually improve after 8 weeks of acute treatment and can progress to partial weight bearing and then full weight bearing by the 4th-5th month. Well-fitting shoes and podiatry referral are essential at this stage to prevent chronic deformities, skin ulceration, and infections.

(Choice B) Custom or prefabricated orthotic shoe inserts are often recommended for conditions related to overuse injuries or foot deformities (eg, pes planus). However, they are not first-line intervention for Charcot joint.

(Choice C) Avoidance of weight bearing on the affected joint rather than physical therapy is recommended.

(Choice D) Sulfasalazine and acetaminophen are warranted for certain inflammatory arthropathies (eg, rheumatoid arthritis) but are not as beneficial for Charcot joint.

(Choice E) Surgical intervention is avoided in most patients due to a 27% failure rate.

stem:
A 72-year-old man presents with 4 weeks of central low back pain. His pain was initially mild and relieved by recumbency. Over the past two weeks, the pain has increased in severity and occurs at night without relief by lying down. The pain does not radiate and he has neither sensory loss nor weakness in his legs. The patient has benign prostatic hyperplasia with significant outlet obstruction. He is scheduled for a transurethral prostatectomy soon. He was treated for a urinary tract infection both 3 years ago and two months ago. He has a history of stable coronary artery disease, hypertension, and degenerative joint disease. He has no history of cancer. His temperature is 37.8 C (100.1 F), blood pressure is 140/72 mm Hg, and pulse is 84/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. There is decreased range of motion in all aspects of his back. Point tenderness is present over the third and fourth lumbar processes. There are no sensory or motor deficits in his lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are symmetric. Perineal sensation and rectal tone are normal. An enlarged, non-tender rubbery prostate is palpated on digital rectal examination.

The patient's labs reveal:
Complete blood count
Hematocrit: 38%
Platelets: 350,000/mm3
Leukocyte count: 9,000/mm3
Serum chemistry
Sodium: 140 mEq/L
Potassium: 4.5 mEq/L
Chloride: 100 mEq/L
Bicarbonate: 24 mEq/L
Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
Blood glucose: 120 mg/dL
Urine
Specific gravity: 1.015
Blood: negative
Leukocyte esterase: trace
Nitrite: positive
WBC: 20-30/hpf
RBC: 1-2/hpf
Casts: none
Hematology
ESR (Westergren): 90 mm/h
explanation:
This patient's clinical presentation is most concerning for vertebral osteomyelitis, most commonly occurring in males over age 50. The majority of low back pain is due to musculoskeletal causes, but the above red flags suggest a systemic disorder. Bacteria from an infected genitourinary source may spread to bone or travel into the lumbar vertebrae and adjacent structures via Batson's venous plexus (present in males). Patients typically present with pain initially relieved by bed rest that eventually worsens at night, point tenderness to palpation on examination, and elevated ESR (sometimes > 100 mm/h). A vertebral body or interspace infection is likely in this patient with a history of infected and obstructive uropathy, constitutional symptoms, subjective fever, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 90. A spinal MRI is the most sensitive test for detecting vertebral osteomyelitis. Treatment is with intravenous antibiotics and surgery for those who do not improve with antibiotics.

(Choices A and C) Pain control with either NSAIDs or acetaminophen with oxycodone may be effective as initial treatment of simple back pain in a patient without red flags for systemic illnesses or anatomic pathology. If a patient fails treatment after 2 weeks, further investigation can be done at that time with MRI or CT.

(Choice D) Prostate biopsy is indicated if digital rectal examination shows nodules, induration, or asymmetry. However, it would not be diagnostic in this patient with known prostate enlargement, infection, and scheduled prostatectomy.

(Choice E) Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) helps in the diagnosis multiple myeloma. However, this patient's clinical presentation is more concerning for an infectious etiology and warrants a MRI.

stem: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening right shoulder stiffness for the last 3 months. She denies any trauma or previous shoulder problems. She also reports a history of chronic low back pain and knee pain. She works as a librarian and has been lifting more books recently since her library expanded its book collection. Her other medical problems include diabetes, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Her temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 14/min Her lungs are clear and her heart sounds are normal. Muscle strength is 5/5 in the lower extremities with intact sensation and 5/5 in the biceps bilaterally. She has markedly decreased passive and active range of motion in right shoulder. Her reflexes are 2+ throughout and she has a normal gait. The remainder of her physical examination is within normal limits.
explanation:
This patient's presentation is most consistent with adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder syndrome). This results from chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and contracture of the joint capsule. Adhesive capsulitis (AC) can be idiopathic or due to underlying conditions such as rotator cuff tendinopathy, subacromial bursitis, stroke, diabetes, or humeral head fracture. Patients typically present with gradual onset of more shoulder stiffness than pain with an inability to reach objects or rotate their shoulder. Diagnosis is confirmed on examination with > 50% reduction in both passive and active range of motion. Adhesive capsulitis is a self-limited condition and responds to conservative management in > 90% of patients. However, complete recovery can take up to 6-18 months in some patients. Pain can be controlled with NSAIDs for 1-2 weeks. Stretching exercises to improve range of motion is the treatment of choice. These include pendulum-type swinging of hand held weights, stretching the arm by walking the fingers up a wall, and rubbing the lower back with a towel with both hands.

(Choice A) Limiting the activity that predisposed the patient to adhesive capsulitis (e.g., lifting books in this patient) is usually recommended with range of motion exercises to prevent worsening of AC and improve joint mobility. Complete rest may worsen joint stiffening and promote adhesions. NSAIDs can be given for 1-2 weeks to decrease the pain and to help patients perform exercises more comfortably.

(Choice B) Oral steroids may be effective for acute AC symptoms, but relief usually lasts only 6 weeks and is not as effective as steroid joint injections.

(Choice D) Steroid joint injection is reserved for patients with persistent AC symptoms 6-8 weeks after range of motion exercises, especially in patients with concurrent rotator cuff or bicipital tendinopathy.

(Choice E) Rotator cuff strengthening exercises are more useful in patients with underlying rotator cuff tendinopathy that may lead to AC. However, they are added after range of motion improves. Strengthening attempted before range of motion improvement may possibly lead to a further decline of range of motion.

stem: A 55-year-old man with a history of gout comes to the physician because of progressively worsening pain and swelling in his right knee that started overnight. The patient took two over-the-counter ibuprofen tablets earlier in the day, which were ineffective. He was diagnosed with gout six months ago when he had an ankle effusion, and he was started on allopurinol at that time. His other medical problems include recurrent renal stones, hypertension, and chronic rotator cuff tendinitis. His home medications include benazepril and allopurinol 100 mg daily. On examination, the right knee appears swollen and tender. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 12,200 cells/μL, serum creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL uric acid level of 9 mg/dL (11 mg/dL 6 months ago), and normal liver function tests. Knee aspiration reveals monosodium urate crystals.
choice_a: Continue same-dose allopurinol and start colchicine
choice_d: Increase allopurinol dose and start colchicine
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with an acute gouty attack, which is evident by the positive synovial fluid crystals. NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for acute gout. Since this patient has already taken ibuprofen, colchicine or corticosteroids (oral or intra-articular) can be used as an alternative therapy. Once the acute attack subsides, prevention of future attacks involves dietary and lifestyle changes (e.g., weight loss, decrease alcohol intake, discontinue diuretics). Patients with recurrent attacks after making appropriate lifestyle changes require pharmacotherapy for prophylaxis. Other indications for prophylaxis include nephrolithiasis, tophaceous gout, x-ray findings of gouty arthritis, or urinary uric acid excretion > 1100 mg/day. Allopurinol is preferred by most clinicians for prophylaxis, and prophylactic colchicine is frequently started at the same time to prevent acute gouty attacks. The allopurinol dose is increased until the patient's serum uric acid level is < 6 mg/dL Prophylactic colchicine is usually given for 6 months after the uric acid level normalizes. Patients who develop an acute gouty attack while taking allopurinol should not stop the drug or have their dose adjusted, since this can worsen the acute attack (Choices B & D). The allopurinol dose may be adjusted 3-4 weeks after the acute inflammation subsides.

(Choice C) Febuxostat is also a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is usually reserved for patients who cannot tolerate allopurinol or have mild to moderate chronic kidney disease. This patient appears to be tolerating allopurinol and has normal kidney function.

(Choice E) Intravenous pegloticase is a novel agent and a treatment option for patients who have chronic gout refractory to other available treatments.

stem: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician with knee pain that started 2 weeks earlier. The pain is localized anteriorly in both knees and is greater in the left. She moved to a new 2-story house 3 weeks ago and has used the stairs many times. Lately she has experienced severe pain when ascending or descending the stairs. The pain also increases after prolonged rest. The patient has no obvious knee trauma or swelling. When she tried to run every day 3 months ago, she developed similar symptoms and had to stop. Her only other medical problem is psoriasis on her elbows, for which she uses corticosteroid and vitamin D combination ointment. Vital signs are normal. BMI is 34 kg/m2. There is no joint line tenderness, redness, warmth, or effusion noted in either knee. Range of motion is normal with mild crepitus. Directly compressing the patella while the leg is extended elicits pain. Valgus and varus stress testing are normal. Lachman, McMurray, and anterior and posterior drawer tests are normal.
explanation:
This patient's anterior knee pain is most likely due to patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS), the most common etiology for nontraumatic knee pain. Risk factors include overuse, malalignment, and trauma, although overuse during training is probably most common. PFPS is usually diagnosed based on history and examination. Most patients complain of "achy" or "sharp" pain under or around the patella. Some patients report the affected knee as "giving way" or "buckling"; these symptoms should not be confused with those of anterior cruciate ligament injury. Some may complain of knee "locking," but the presence of true locking and joint effusions indicates intra-articular pathology (eg, meniscal injury). The knee pain typically worsens after prolonged rest and with activities such as squatting, running, or going up and down stairs. Examination shows normal range of motion, mild crepitus, and retropatellar pain with direct compression of the patella during knee extension. Obesity, weakness, and/or quadriceps atrophy may be present. Supervised physical therapy involving activity modification and quadriceps plus hip abductor strengthening for at least 6-12 months is the mainstay of treatment. NSAIDS and bracing are often tried but have not demonstrated long-term benefit in clinical studies (Choice A). However, NSAIDs can be tried for short-term pain relief while physical therapy takes effect.

(Choice B) Clinical studies have not found corticosteroid injections to be an effective long-term solution for PFPS.

(Choice D) MRI is indicated only when a meniscal or ligamentous injury is suspected. This patient has no knee swelling, joint instability or abnormal valgus/varus tests, so no MRI is required.

(Choice C) Methotrexate is used for psoriatic arthritis, but this patient's examination findings (retropatellar pain) are most likely due to PFPS.

stem: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple oral ulcers that have occurred intermittently for the last two months. These ulcers are very painful and are associated with fatigue and low grade fever. She is a teacher and several of her kindergarten students have been ill with hand-foot-and- mouth disease. She has a five-year history of a clinical diagnosis of genital herpes with intermittent flares requiring oral acyclovir. Her mother has an unspecified autoimmune disease with joint pains for which she has taken intermittent steroid therapy over the last 10 years. Physical examination reveals three vesicular lesions on her buccal and gingival mucosa and acneiform lesions on her face and back. Scars are noted on the patient's vulvar area. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
explanation:
This patient's presentation of recurrent oral ulcers, acne, and genital ulcers is most consistent with Behçet disease. While her genital ulcers have been attributed to Herpes simplex type 2, there is no reported viral documentation. Behçet disease is a vasculitis of either small (most common), medium, or large vessels that involves multiple organs. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings (recurrent oral aphthous ulcers > 3 times/year) plus two of the following: eye lesions, recurrent genital lesions, skin lesions, or positive pathergy (≥2 mm papule forming 24-48 hours after inserting a 20-25 gauge needle 5 mm into skin). Treatment usually involves steroids and directed therapy towards the involved organ system.

(Choice A) Aphthous stomatitis lesions are nearly identical to those of Behçet, but they are usually not associated with the acneiform lesions and genital ulcers seen in this patient.

(Choice C) Coxsackie virus (hand-foot-and-mouth syndrome) occurs more commonly in children and usually presents with fever, sore throat, and oral or palmar/plantar lesions sparing the lips and gingiva. This patient's recurrent lesions and lack of palmar/plantar lesions makes this unlikely.

(Choice D) Vulvar or scrotal scarring occurs very rarely in conditions other than Behçet disease. Also, given the patients family history of autoimmune disease and acne, Behçet disease is more likely than any other diagnosis.

(Choice E) Nearly 50% of lupus patients can have lip and oral mucosal involvement with plaques (discoid lesions), erythematous lesions, punched out erosions, or ulcers. However, the oral ulcers (except for discoid lesions) are usually painless. This patient's painful ulcers make lupus unlikely.

stem:
A 60-year-old woman comes to the office due to back pain. For the last 3 months, the patient has had dull, achy pain in the lumbar area radiating to the buttocks bilaterally. The pain is worse with lifting heavy boxes and is not relieved with acetaminophen or heating pads. She has had no fever, weight change, dysuria, incontinence, abdominal pain, or muscular weakness. The patient's medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she takes chlorthalidone, and osteoarthritis of the knees and hands. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Blood pressure is 148/98 mm Hg and pulse is 84/min. BMI is 32 kg/m2. Examination shows normal range of motion in the lumbar spine. Lower extremity strength, sensation, and reflexes are normal. Straight leg raise causes worsening of pain in the back but no radiation of pain.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Serum chemistry
Sodium: 133 mEq/L
Potassium: 3.5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen: 18 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Glucose: 105 mg/dL
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 12.2 g/dL
Leukocytes: 5,500/mm3
Platelets: 250,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 15 mm/hr

MRI of the lumbar spine shows a mild L4-L5 disc bulge without neural impingement and moderate facet arthropathy at multiple levels.
explanation:
This patient has uncomplicated back pain with no systemic symptoms or neurologic deficits. Back pain can be categorized as acute (<4 weeks), subacute (4-12 weeks), or chronic (>12 weeks). Acute back pain usually resolves spontaneously and may be managed conservatively (eg, heating pads, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs). However, chronic pain is less likely to improve without additional interventions. Also, imaging is not usually necessary in acute pain; it can be considered for patients with chronic pain, but frequently shows nonspecific findings (eg, degenerative changes, disc herniations) that do not correlate with symptoms, as in this patient. Management of chronic back pain should emphasize nonpharmacologic measures. A multidisciplinary rehabilitation program, including physical therapy (with recommendations for a home exercise program), occupational therapy, and cognitive-behavioral therapy, has been shown to improve pain and functional status better than a single-modality approach. For obese patients, an effective weight loss program can reduce or eliminate long-term pain.

(Choice A) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (eg, naproxen) can be effective in chronic back pain, although long-term use can be problematic in those, such as this patient, with chronic kidney disease or hypertension. In addition, patients should not be advised to restrict activity but should maintain normal, moderate activity.

(Choice B) Centrally acting muscle relaxants (eg, cyclobenzaprine, tizanidine) are effective for pain relief in patients with acute back pain. However, muscle relaxants are not advised for those with chronic pain, and the risks of carisoprodol (eg, abuse/withdrawal, driving impairment) outweigh the benefits for nearly all patients.

(Choice D) A number of physical modalities for chronic back pain, such as transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, back braces, traction devices, and shortwave diathermy, have been promoted in the lay media. Evidence of benefit for these treatments is generally of low quality and shows inconsistent benefits. They are not currently recommended.

(Choice E) Epidural glucocorticoids can be considered for patients with persistent pain due to lumbosacral radiculopathy if noninvasive management is ineffective. Glucocorticoid injections (eg, epidural, facet joints) are not effective for uncomplicated nonradicular chronic back pain (as in this patient).

stem: A 65-year-old woman with known chronic obstructive pulmonary disease seeks evaluation due to pain in both of her knees and warmth in her fingertips. She has a 50-pack-year smoking history and quit 5 years ago. She has never been hospitalized for respiratory symptoms. The patient uses a tiotropium inhaler daily and albuterol as needed for shortness of breath. She also takes lisinopril for hypertension and bisacodyl for chronic constipation. Her blood pressure is 144/85 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min. She has decreased breath sounds bilaterally and a mildly prolonged expiratory phase of respiration. There is a grade 1/6 systolic murmur along the left upper sternal border. The finger joints and both knees have some mild warmth and slight tenderness to palpation, with normal range of motion. Mild finger clubbing is present.
explanation:
This patient's smoking history, clubbing, and symptoms of periosteal inflammation suggest hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (HOA), which is characterized by abnormal proliferation of the skin and osseous tissue. HOA is most commonly due to an intrathoracic process, frequently non-small cell lung cancer. Other intrathoracic causes of clubbing with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy include cystic fibrosis, chronic lung infections, and cyanotic heart disease with right-to-left intracardiac shunts. Patients presenting with HOA warrant thoracic imaging with chest x-ray or CT to rule out malignancy. Imaging of the painful joints would reveal periosteal new bone formation.

(Choice B) Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can relieve the pain. However, symptomatic therapy alone misses the opportunity to detect an underlying lung cancer. Resection of the mass may lead to resolution of joint symptoms in some patients.

(Choice C) Chronic liver disorders, including cirrhosis, can lead to clubbing, but this is uncommon.

(Choice D) Because most individuals with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are or have been smokers, there is a higher frequency of intrathoracic neoplasms in this population. However, COPD per se does not result in clubbing, and treating COPD with glucocorticoids or bronchodilators does not relieve HOA.

(Choice E) Cyanotic heart disease with a right-to-left shunt can result in clubbing. This patient has a murmur that is likely due to age-related aortic sclerosis or mild aortic stenosis, but there are no additional cardiac findings that suggest a shunt.

stem:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of hand pain and swelling that lasts several hours every morning. She has not felt well since "getting the flu" two weeks ago from her two children (ages 4 and 6). She initially had a sore throat and fever without rash, cough, dysuria, or diarrhea. She works as a flight attendant and travels extensively, but has been on medical leave for the past two weeks due to her illness. She is in a monogamous relationship and uses a barrier method for contraception. She does not smoke, but she drinks alcohol occasionally. Her vital signs are within normal limits. There are no skin rashes. Oropharyngeal examination shows mild tonsillar swelling and normal appearing pharyngeal mucosa. Several 0.5 cm non-tender lymph nodes are palpable in the anterior cervical region. Auscultation of the heart and lungs is normal. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. The small joints of her hands and wrists are swollen and tender. She is unable to flex or extend her wrists or make a fist due to the pain and swelling. She has normal range of motion without swelling in both knees, ankles, shoulders, and feet.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 11.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 80 fL
Platelets: 320,000 cells/μL
Leukocyte count: 8,900 cells/μL
Serum chemistry
Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
Immunologic and rheumatologic studies
Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): 1:80 (nucleolar pattern)
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 35 mm/h
Rheumatoid factor: 51 U/mL
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with likely parvovirus infection. The classic "slapped cheek" rash is less common in adults than children. Adults usually present with flu-like symptoms 5-10 days after exposure followed by acute symmetrical arthralgias/arthritis (e.g., hands/wrists) that can resemble rheumatoid arthritis. Patients with preexisting hematologic disease (e.g., sickle cell) can develop a transient aplastic crisis, while immunocompromised patients can develop acute or chronic anemia due to bone marrow suppression of erythroid precursors. Patients may have a positive rheumatoid factor (RF), but rheumatoid arthritis should not be diagnosed by RF alone if symptoms are < 6 weeks in duration (Choice D). Acute infection is confirmed with parvovirus B19 IgM antibodies, which increase within the first month of illness and often become undetectable after 2- 3 months. Parvovirus IgG antibodies reflect past exposure and are not diagnostic, since up to 50% of healthy people may have parvovirus IgG antibodies. Arthritis caused by parvovirus infection is self-limiting and usually resolves in 1-2 months. Treatment is mainly supportive with monitoring, since there is no currently effective vaccine or pharmacotherapy.

(Choice A) Acute rheumatic fever usually presents with fever and migratory arthritis involving the large joints (e.g., knees), but it may involve the ankles and elbows as well. However, this patient does not have migratory arthritis or other major criteria (e.g., chorea, erythema marginatum, pancarditis, subcutaneous nodules) to suggest rheumatic fever.

(Choice B) Infectious mononucleosis typically presents with fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and atypical lymphocytosis. Patients can also have splenomegaly and a generalized rash, but usually do not present with the symmetric arthritis seen in this patient.

(Choice E) Nearly 5-10% of healthy patients can have a positive ANA, usually at a low titer (e.g., 1:40). Parvovirus can cause a false-positive ANA, and this patient does not have other clinical symptoms (e.g., malar rash, photosensitivity) to suggest SLE.

stem: A 34-year-old man comes to the office with 2 weeks of left forefoot pain. He is a runner and has participated in many marathons without any problem. For the past 2 months, he has been training for a cross-country race with hill runs. His pain has worsened to the point that he has had to stop in the middle of many training sessions. The pain improves with rest. Holding the left second toe and pushing it in toward the foot produces pain. X-rays of the left foot are normal.
explanation:
This patient's presentation suggests a metatarsal shaft stress fracture, which is usually due to repetitive weight-bearing activities (eg, running, dancing, jumping) injuring the forefoot. Risk factors include anatomic defects (eg, pes planus), obesity, female athlete triad (oligo-/amenorrhea, decreased caloric intake, and osteopenia/porosis), and poorly fitting shoes. Bone can remodel in response to mechanical stress, but abruptly increasing physical activity (intensity, duration, or frequency) without adequate rest causes repeated tension or compressive stress, leading to microfractures and eventually to a discontinuity of the cortical bone. Metatarsal stress fractures occur most commonly in the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th metatarsal shafts. Patients usually develop gradually worsening forefoot pain and with continued activity can progress to swelling or frank fracture. Examination may show focal tenderness, or holding the corresponding toe at the same level as the metatarsal and pushing it in along the long axis of the metatarsal (axial loading) may elicit the pain. The diagnosis is made clinically but may require imaging in uncertain cases. Plain x-rays can be normal up to 6 weeks after symptom onset, and more sensitive modalities (eg, MRI, bone scan) may be required for definitive diagnosis.

(Choice A) Morton neuroma is associated with numbness or pain between the third and fourth toes and with a clicking sensation (Mulder sign) that occurs when this space is palpated and the metatarsal joints are squeezed simultaneously.

(Choice B) Plantar fasciitis causes burning pain in the plantar (not dorsal) area of the rearfoot that worsens with the first steps in the morning. The pain decreases as activity increases during the day but can worsen at the end of the day with prolonged weight bearing. Point tenderness is the hallmark.

(Choice C) Sesamoiditis usually presents with focal pain of the sesamoid bones on the plantar surface of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The pain typically increases with walking, running, and dorsiflexion of the great toe.

(Choice E) Tarsal tunnel syndrome is due to compression of the tibial nerve as it passes through the ankle. It usually develops after acute bony injuries. Patients develop burning, numbness, and aching of the distal plantar (not dorsal) surface of the foot/toes that may radiate up to the heel and calf.

stem:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician with a rash on her hands for the past 2 weeks. Two months ago she developed a rash on her face and forearms while vacationing at a beach resort. Her review of systems is positive for recent onset weakness of the shoulders and hips. She has no dysphagia, shortness of breath, fever, chills, or weight loss. She is a lifetime nonsmoker. Her temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 14/min. Her BMI is 21 kg/m2. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Range of motion of the spine is normal and without pain, scoliosis, or excessive kyphosis of the back. Upper and lower limb deep-tendon reflexes are 2+. She has difficulty rising from a chair. Muscle strength is 4/5 in both upper and lower extremities.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 12.5 g/dL
Platelets: 180,000/μL
Leukocytes: 4,100/μL
Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
Calcium: 9.4 mg/dL
Total protein: 6.5 g/dL
Albumin: 3.7 g/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 100 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 96 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 120 U/L
Thyroid-stimulating hormone: 3.4 μU/mL
Serum creatine kinase: 1040 U/L
Anti-nuclear antibody (ANA): 1:160, nucleolar pattern
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 68 mm/h
The rash is shown in the photograph.
explanation:
This patient's muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase suggest a myopathic process. The characteristic rash in the hands (Gottron's papules located over the metacarpophalangeal joints) and history of photosensitive rash (shawl sign) suggest dermatomyositis as the most likely diagnosis. Up to 50% of patients may also present with violaceous periorbital rash in the upper eyelid (heliotrope rash). Patients with inflammatory myopathy (dermatomyositis and polymyositis) are at fivefold increased risk of malignancy compared to the general population. Thus, screening should include age-appropriate cancer screening tests (eg, mammogram and colonoscopy) in all patients, and additional tests in high-risk patients (eg, CT of the chest/abdomen/pelvis, UA, serum CA125/CA19-9/PSA, UGI endoscopy).

(Choice A) This patient's rash on the hands and muscle weakness with elevated CK are not characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). SLE can cause myalgias and is somewhat less likely (<15%) to present in a patient of this age.

(Choice C) Optic neuritis is rarely associated with systemic inflammatory disorders (eg, SLE and Wegener's granulomatosis). Patients typically present with painful unilateral vision loss over several hours to days. Funduscopic examination may be normal or show visible optic nerve inflammation.

(Choice D) Liver biopsy may be indicated in patients with elevated transaminase levels, but this patient likely has a muscular source of the elevated enzymes due to inflammatory muscle disease.

(Choice E) High-dose steroids are usually indicated for treating dermatomyositis. Initial low-dose steroids are frequently used for polymyalgia rheumatica.

stem: A 43-year-old attorney comes to the office because of pain in his right lower extremity. He is an avid tennis player, and lately, he has started to notice pain in his right groin area whenever he runs or jogs. The pain is described as a soreness that travels down his anterior thigh toward his knee. It is present with moderate activity and improves with rest. Lying on his right side does not affect the pain. There is no associated numbness or muscle weakness. His temperature is 37.2 C (98.9 F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 12/min. His cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. His hip examination reveals pain along the anterior hip worsened with internal and external rotation.
explanation:
Hip pain is most commonly caused by trochanteric and gluteus medius bursitis, femoral fractures, and osteoarthritis (most likely in this patient). Patients with osteoarthritis typically complain of morning stiffness and groin pain. The pain may radiate towards the knee, but does not extend beyond it. Rest tends to ameliorate the pain, but lying on either side would not affect the pain. Pain is often aggravated by movement (internal/external rotation) rather than by direct pressure, as in trochanteric bursitis. Plain x-rays (weight bearing AP pelvis) can confirm osteoarthritis by showing a decreased joint space, sclerosis of the joint space margins, and periarticular osteophytes. Treatment usually involves rest and NSAIDS.

(Choice A) A hamstring injury would present with pain felt over the buttock area and may extend to the trochanteric bursa area, but would not be felt anteriorly in the thigh.

(Choice B) Patients with meralgia paresthetica complain of burning pain, paresthesia, and diminished sensation over the upper outer thigh. The most common predisposing factor is obesity with an overlying panniculus and is caused by compression of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve.

(Choice C) Occult hip fracture typically presents with acute onset of severe pain after an injury. Patients have pain with any slight hip movement and difficulty bearing weight, neither of which was present in this patient.

(Choice E) Trochanteric bursitis usually presents with pain/point tenderness over the greater trochanter that is worse when lying on the affected side. The most common cause of trochanteric bursitis is disturbance of gait from any cause (e.g., lumbosacral spine disease (75%), leg length discrepancy (10%), etc.). Examination of the hip is usually normal.

stem:
A 73-year-old woman comes to the office because of achiness. She began to notice pain around her shoulders and hips six weeks ago. The symptoms developed abruptly without an antecedent illness. She notes considerable stiffness around her neck and shoulders in the morning when she gets out of bed and has difficulty dressing herself. She has some soreness in both hips, but these symptoms slowly clear by midday. She denies any cranial complaints. She has never had similar muscle or joint achiness before. She has no fever, chills, weight loss, or headache. She tried over-the-counter ibuprofen, which did not relieve her pain. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, coronary artery disease, transient ischemic attack. Her medications include aspirin, hydrochlorothiazide, hydralazine, isosorbide, a statin, and a beta blocker. She has had no medication changes in the last year. She is allergic to angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors. Physical examination is within normal limits except for some mild restriction of bilateral shoulder abduction. She does not have any swollen joints.

Her laboratory results are as follows:
Creatine kinase, serum: 132 U/L
Thyroid stimulating hormone: 6.4 μU/mL
Free T4: 1.6 ng/dL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 20 mm/h
C-reactive protein: 24.0 mg/L (Normal ≤ 8 mg/L)
Her complete blood count, serum electrolytes, and liver and kidney function studies are normal.
explanation:
This patient has a subacute onset of aching and morning stiffness in the shoulders, hip girdles, and neck. This is consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR), a condition of unknown etiology that occurs in about 1% of the population over the age of 50. The great majority of patients with PMR have an elevated ESR (>40 mm/h), but this can be normal in up to 20% of patients. C-reactive protein is elevated (>22 mg/L) in nearly all PMR patients and would be the next step to suggest the diagnosis in patients with a normal ESR. Patients in whom there is still uncertainty can then be treated empirically with low-dose prednisone ( (10-15 mg/day with slow taper over 1-2 years). The diagnosis of PMR is confirmed with a dramatic response and symptom resolution (usually within 3 days) after starting low-dose prednisone.

(Choice A) Drug-induced lupus associated with hydralazine typically presents with myalgias, arthralgias, fever, malaise, rash, and possibly serositis. This patient has no other active systemic symptoms.

(Choice B) Statin myopathy typically starts within weeks to months of drug initiation and presents as proximal and symmetrical muscle weakness with soreness, myalgias, and sometimes elevated creatine kinase (CK). Shoulder and hip stiffness (morning stiffness) is uncommon with statin use.

(Choice C) Amitriptyline is not effective for the management of PMR; but it is used for fibromyalgia, which can also cause widespread achiness. However, fibromyalgia occurs less frequently in older individuals and is not localized to the shoulder or hip girdle areas, as in this patient.

(Choice D) Hypothyroidism may cause symptoms similar to PMR, but is less likely in this patient with subclinical hypothyroidism.

stem: A 63-year-old woman comes to the office due to several months of bilateral leg pain, predominantly in her calves and thighs when she walks. After a block or two, she experiences numbness in both calves and thighs that progresses to pain and weakness with continued walking. The patient's symptoms worsen when she walks downhill, and the pain and numbness quickly subside with rest. Her symptoms often occur at the grocery store, but are relieved when she leans over a cart. She also has lower back pain. The patient has no bladder and/or bowel symptoms, chest pain, chest pressure, dyspnea, or edema. The patient's medical problems include hypertension, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hyperlipidemia, and degenerative joint disease. She also has a history of coronary artery disease with stent placement in her right coronary artery 2 years ago. Her medications include atorvastatin, metoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, lisinopril, and omeprazole. The patient's blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min. A bruit is heard over the right carotid artery. There are no abdominal or femoral bruits. Her femoral, popliteal, and dorsalis pedal pulses are normal and symmetric. There are no trophic changes of the skin or nails in the feet. Straight leg raising test is negative. The patient can walk on her heels and toes. There are no lower extremity sensory deficits. Lower extremity deep-tendon reflexes are 2+ and symmetric. Perineal sensation is normal.
explanation:
This patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis, which occurs most commonly in adults age >60 due to degenerative spondylosis. Patients typically present with a syndrome of bilateral pain (pseudoclaudication) that is worsened when walking with the spine extended (eg, downhill more than uphill) or with prolonged periods of standing upright. Both activities decrease the diameter of the spinal canal and cause mechanical and/or ischemic disruption of nerve root function. Symptoms are usually relieved with rest or bending forward while walking (eg, leaning over a cart) as these maneuvers increase the diameter of the spinal canal. Pseudoclaudication may resemble vascular claudication, but the lower extremity pulses are usually normal. Lower extremity neurologic examination may also be normal, although objective weakness may be seen in advanced disease. Lumbar MRI is the preferred test as it best visualizes the soft tissues and neural structures (eg, conus medullaris, spinal nerve roots).

(Choice A) Although abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and occlusive peripheral vascular disease can co- exist, most AAAs remain asymptomatic until they rupture. It would be unlikely for this patient's symptoms to be caused by an AAA.

(Choice B) Reduced ankle-brachial index (ABI) indicates vascular claudication due to extensive atherosclerotic vascular disease. Lower extremity pulses are usually diminished. However, ABI is usually normal in lumbar stenosis.

(Choice C) Bone scan is useful to diagnose metastatic lesions but would be unlikely to be diagnostic in this patient who has no point tenderness of her back, no history of cancer, and no evidence of cauda equina syndrome.

(Choice E) Nerve conduction studies are diagnostic for peripheral neuropathy, but this patient's symptoms do not suggest this condition.

stem:
A 60-year-old woman comes to the office due to frequent urination. She gets up 3 times a night to urinate and drink water. She has also noticed some mild hoarseness, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. Her eyes have been dry and "burning," for which she uses over-the-counter eye drops. The patient has no history of chronic medical conditions but has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Blood pressure is 144/78 mm Hg and pulse is 82/min and regular. Physical examination is unremarkable.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Complete blood count
Hematocrit: 34%
Leukocytes: 7,500/mm3
Serum chemistry
Sodium: 138 mEq/L
Potassium: 3.4 mEq/L
Chloride: 110 mEq/L
Bicarbonate: 18 mEq/L
Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL
Calcium: 9.4 mg/dL
Liver function studies
Total protein: 8.9 g/dL
Albumin: 3.9 g/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 135 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 25 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 30 U/L
Urinalysis
Specific gravity: 1.001
Protein: trace
Blood: negative
Glucose: negative
Nitrites: negative
White blood cells: 1-2/hpf
Red blood cells: 1-2/hpf
Casts: none
explanation:
This patient with dry eyes, hoarseness, and fatigue has an elevated gamma globulin gap (total protein minus albumin >4), raising suspicion for a chronic inflammatory disorder such as Sjögren syndrome (SS). SS is marked by lymphocytic infiltration of the lacrimal and salivary glands, which leads to the characteristic symptoms of dry eyes and dry mouth. Approximately 25% of cases are also accompanied by extraglandular disease of the skin, lungs, nervous system, heart, and/or kidneys. The most common renal manifestation of SS is chronic interstitial nephritis. Patients with this condition usually have mild renal insufficiency, a fairly benign urinalysis, and renal tubular abnormalities such as distal renal tubular acidosis and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Diagnosis usually requires anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibody testing and/or lower lip salivary gland biopsy.

(Choice A) Chest CT scan with contrast could help diagnose sarcoidosis, which can cause an elevated gamma gap and dry eyes. However, most patients with sarcoidosis also have pulmonary, skin, and/or joint manifestations.

(Choice C) Renal biopsy would likely show interstitial nephritis, but this finding would not be diagnostic of SS specifically. Diagnosis must be established with anti-SSA/SSB testing and/or lip biopsy.

(Choice D) Multiple myeloma can cause an elevated gamma gap and renal insufficiency, but bone pain and hypercalcemia are more common. Dry eyes and hoarseness would be uncommon.

(Choice E) Chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) can cause an SS-like syndrome, but usually causes glomerular injury with nephrotic/nephritic patterns on urinalysis.

stem:
A 52-year-old man with a history of rheumatoid arthritis comes to the clinic due to increasing pain and swelling involving several joints over the past 6 weeks. The patient also has fatigue and morning stiffness that can last for hours. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 2 years ago after he presented with symmetrical polyarthritis, a high-titer rheumatoid factor, and positive cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Treatment with methotrexate and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents resulted in reduction of joint pain and swelling. At his last visit 3 months ago, the patient had only mild joint pains without any morning stiffness. His other medical problems include hypertension, diverticulosis, and hyperlipidemia. His temperature is 37.4 C (99.4 F), blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 77/min. Gentle squeezing of his hands and feet evokes pain. Several small joints of the fingers and toes are swollen and tender. There is mild boggy swelling of the left knee. Subcutaneous nodules are seen over the elbows. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 10.4 g/dL
Platelets: 450,000/mm3
Leukocytes: 9,200/mm3
Creatinine, serum: 0.9 mg/dL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 67 mm/h
explanation:
This patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) had an initial response to methotrexate but now has treatment-resistant disease. Adding a biologic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD), such as a tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF) antagonist, is the most appropriate next step (step-up therapy). However, TNF blockers increase the risk of reactivation of latent tuberculosis (TB). As a result, all patients should undergo TB screening (either skin tuberculin test or interferon-gamma release assay) before starting TNF blockers, and those with positive tests should then be treated for latent TB prior to starting TNF antagonist therapy. Patients should also be screened for hepatitis B and C prior to initiation.

(Choice B) RA is commonly associated with p-ANCA, but it is unclear how specific this finding is without systemic vasculitis.

(Choice C) Lyme disease typically involves large joints (eg, knees). This patient has hand arthritis and no preceding rash, making Lyme disease less likely.

(Choice D) Methotrexate is the most commonly used DMARD and is rarely discontinued unless there is toxicity; this patient requires additional treatment for worsening disease.

(Choice E) Adding another nonbiologic DMARD is acceptable but less preferable than adding a biologic DMARD in this setting.

stem: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician with worsening left knee pain. She has had intermittent pain and stiffness in her left knee for the past 5 years. The pain is aggravated by prolonged standing, but her knee also feels stiff if she sits in 1 place for too long. She was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 3 years ago. The patient initially was treated with systemic steroids, and the disease is currently in remission on oral sulfasalazine. Her other medical problems include hypertension, impaired glucose tolerance, and hypothyroidism. The patient's vital signs are normal. Her BMI is 31 kg/m2 On physical examination, flexion and extension of the left knee joint elicit pain, but there is no instability. There is a small joint effusion. Knee joint aspiration yields 3 mL of synovial fluid. Synovial fluid analysis shows a total cell count of 2000/μL with 25% polymorphonuclear cells. An x-ray of the left knee is shown below.
choice_a: Arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease
explanation:
