This patient has long-standing, worsening knee pain and stiffness. Her symptoms and knee x-ray findings (osteophytes, loss of joint space) are suggestive of osteoarthritis. Patients with osteoarthritis usually have morning stiffness for < 30 minutes, pain that worsens with activity, bony enlargement, and no palpable warmth. Joint fluid analysis shows a non-inflammatory process with a total cell count typically < 2,000/μL. Treatment involves acetaminophen, NSAIDs, or injections.

(Choice A) IBD-associated arthropathy typically presents with acute onset joint pain and inflammatory synovial fluid (total cell count > 2,000/μL, often 5,000-10,000/μL).

(Choice B) Osteonecrosis can occur with steroid use, but is most common in the femoral head. X-rays reveal increased lucency with bony sclerosis.

(Choice C) CPPD (pseudogout) shows positively birefringent crystals and inflammatory fluid with > 50% neutrophils. X-rays reveal chondrocalcinosis.

(Choice E) Patellofemoral pain syndrome affects younger patients and presents with retropatellar pain on compression; there is no joint effusion or narrowing.

stem:
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician with a 3-month history of right groin pain. It initially occurred only during weight-bearing maneuvers but now has become constant. He has no fever, dysuria, or paresthesia. The patient underwent renal transplantation 10 years ago due to polycystic kidney disease. His other medical problems include hypertension and spinal stenosis status post lumbar laminectomy. His medications include prednisone, mycophenolate, and sirolimus. He does not use tobacco or alcohol. His temperature is 37 C (98 F), blood pressure is 114/67 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Range of motion and curvature of the spine are normal with no pain to palpation noted. Internal rotation of the right hip joint is restricted due to pain. There is no warmth, swelling, or erythema to the joint. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Pinprick and light touch sensations are intact.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Leukocytes: 5,500/μL
Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
C-reactive protein: 6 mg/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 22 mm/h
X-ray of the right hip shows mild joint space narrowing between the femur and acetabulum.
choice_c: MRI scan of the hip joint
choice_d: Ultrasound-guided steroid injection of the hip joint
explanation:
This patient's groin pain on weight bearing, limited internal rotation, steroid use, normal vital signs/inflammatory markers, and history of renal transplantation suggest avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femur. AVN is caused by compromised bone blood supply. The pathognomonic sign on late-stage x-ray is the crescent sign, but in early stages, x-rays may be normal or show only mild nonspecific narrowing. If clinical suspicion is high, MRI is the most sensitive means of diagnosing early AVN.

(Choice A) Passive stretching is for trochanteric bursitis, which presents with lateral hip tenderness rather than groin pain during internal rotation.

(Choice B) Indium-111 WBC scans localise infection; osteomyelitis typically presents with local inflammation and elevated markers.

(Choice D) While this patient has mild joint space narrowing, his high risk for AVN (steroids, transplant) makes MRI necessary to rule out AVN before assuming osteoarthritis and injecting steroids.

(Choice E) The patient has no back pain or radicular symptoms to warrant spinal imaging.

stem: An 80-year-old man comes to the office due to generalized weakness and intermittently feeling "dizzy" and unsteady over the past year. He fell 9 months ago when he tripped over a step. The patient has had no syncope or chest pain and has not attempted to use any mobility aids. History is notable for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, osteoarthritis, coronary artery disease, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, atenolol, simvastatin, and omeprazole. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol. Blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and pulse is 68/min. There are no orthostatic changes. BMI is 30 kg/m2 Examination shows normal jugular venous pressure, clear lung fields, and normal S1 and S2. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is no tenderness to palpation of the lower back. There are symmetric joint deformities of both knees and generalized arthritic changes in both hands. Cranial nerve examination is normal. Muscle power is 4/5 in both upper and lower extremities. Pinprick and light touch sensations are mildly decreased in both feet. Achilles reflexes are absent bilaterally. Complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and vitamin D levels are normal. Hemoglobin A1c is 8.2%. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm and old Q waves in lateral leads.
explanation:
This elderly patient with nonspecific weakness and dizziness on ambulation is likely experiencing disequilibrium. Disequilibrium is common in older individuals with multiple chronic disorders and increased fall risk. The etiology is likely multifactorial (neuropathy, muscle weakness, arthritis, medications). Management requires a multidisciplinary program including regular exercise and physical therapy. Strengthening exercise education is best provided in a supervised physical therapy program.

(Choice A) Pacemakers are for symptomatic bradycardia (syncope/presyncope); this patient has no bradycardia or block on ECG.

(Choice B) Education is part of assessment, but supervised exercise/therapy is more effective for improving balance and strength.

(Choice C) Tight glucose control in the elderly increases hypoglycemia risk and fall risk. A target A1c of <8.5% is often appropriate for complex patients.

(Choice D) Intensive blood pressure control is associated with an increased risk of falls in patients over 80.

stem:
A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of a two-month history of right-sided neck, shoulder, and arm pain. The onset of the pain occurred a few days after he spent an afternoon chopping firewood. He describes the pain as constant and occasionally pulsating, especially at night. He also notes that his right arm alternates between warm and cold to the touch. He gets partial pain relief when he applies ice to the affected areas. He tried over-the-counter acetaminophen and ibuprofen without relief. His other medical problems include hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. His medications include losartan, amlodipine, omeprazole, and simvastatin. Physical examination is remarkable for tenderness over the right occipital area. There is mild edema of the fingers on the right hand. Neck motion is complete but slow in all directions. Neurological examination, including pinprick, motor strength, and deep tendon reflexes of the upper extremities, is unremarkable. 

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 14.2 g/dL
Platelets: 250,000 cells/μL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 15 mm/h

Radiographs of the cervical spine show some mild disk space narrowing at C5-C6 and C6-C7. A right shoulder x-ray demonstrates normal alignment, no fractures, and no calcifications. There is some patchy bone demineralization involving the acromion.
explanation:
This patient's presentation is most consistent with complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS), which commonly occurs after an injury. Stage 1 features include limb pain (throbbing/aching, sensitive to cold), local edema, changes in color/temperature, and patchy bone demineralization on x-ray. CRPS likely involves a reflex arc along the sympathetic nervous system leading to autonomic symptoms (swelling, coldness). Diagnosis is clinical based on symptoms and relief with local anesthetic block.

(Choice A) Cervical radiculopathy usually follows a specific nerve root distribution; this patient's symptoms traverse multiple roots and include vasomotor symptoms.

(Choice C) Fibromyalgia presents with widespread tender points on both sides of the body, unlike these localized symptoms.

(Choice D) PMR presents with bilateral shoulder girdle stiffness in patients > 50 and lacks the paresthesias and temperature changes seen here.

(Choice E) Systemic sclerosis is usually bilateral and associated with specific skin hardening/Raynaud's rather than unilateral temperature changes without color changes.

stem: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of pain and swelling in his right leg. He experienced pain in his right calf the night before that he thought was related to playing softball the previous day. He recalled no injury while playing. The pain progressed and he now has slight swelling in the right foot. The patient has not had a similar problem previously. He has no fever, chills, chest pain, or dyspnea. His other medical problems include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and degenerative joint disease of both knees. Vital signs are normal. There is 1+ pedal edema on the right leg and no edema on the left. Peripheral pulses are full and symmetric. There is no obvious difference in temperature between the legs. There is no erythema or palpable cords. Homan's sign is strongly positive on the right. There may be a small effusion of the right knee. The patient has nonpulsatile fullness in the right popliteal fossa when standing with his legs fully extended.
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with a popliteal synovial cyst (Baker's cyst). Dissecting cysts often result in a "pseudo-thrombophlebitis" syndrome causing calf tenderness, positive Homan's sign, and edema. Physical examination shows prominent medial popliteal fullness with the patient standing and knees extended (Foucher's sign). Underlying joint disease (osteoarthritis) is a major risk factor.

(Choice A) DVT also presents with swelling and Homan's sign, but posterior knee fullness and joint effusion favor a dissecting cyst.

(Choice B) Popliteal aneurysms usually present as a pulsatile mass.

(Choice D) Sarcoma presents as solid fullness but is less common than popliteal cysts in the setting of known osteoarthritis.

(Choice E) Torn gastrocnemius causes localized pain and possible hematoma but is not associated with knee swelling.

stem: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening hip pain over the last several weeks. The pain is localized to the lateral aspect of her left hip over the outer thigh, but sometimes extends to her left buttock and knee. Her pain increases when she climbs stairs, gets out of the car, and stands up from sitting in a deep chair. She also notes that the pain sometimes occurs with walking or prolonged standing. On occasion, the pain awakens her from sleep when she rolls onto her left side. She denies fever, chills, or constitutional symptoms. She cannot recall any trauma to the area and has had no falls. Her medical problems include obesity (BMI 30 kg/m2), type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic low back pain, and depression.
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with trochanteric bursitis, caused by exaggerated movement of the gluteus medius tendon over the femur. Patients present with lateral hip pain worsened by repetitive hip flexion (climbing stairs) or lying on the affected side. Physical examination typically reveals local tenderness over the midpoint of the greater trochanter during flexion. Treatment includes local heat, weight reduction, and NSAIDs.

(Choice A) Claudication from aortoiliac disease causes aching pain in the buttock/hip with activity but is usually not localized to the lateral hip.

(Choice B) Spinal stenosis produces back pain radiating into the buttock/thigh, usually bilateral and posture-dependent.

(Choice C) Meralgia paresthetica (lateral femoral cutaneous nerve entrapment) causes decreased sensation/paresthesia over the antero-lateral upper thigh rather than localized trochanteric pain.

(Choice D) Osteoarthritis of the hip is associated with groin pain rather than lateral hip pain, and is often accompanied by limited range of motion.

stem: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician due to attacks of joint pain and swelling that affect primarily his hands but sometimes his knees or elbows. He currently has no pain, but the episodes occur once or twice a month. The patient's other medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He has not seen a physician for 2 years, and he has managed his diabetes with diet. He was diagnosed with arthritis 2 years ago at a different clinic and was prescribed ibuprofen. The patient smokes 1-2 packs of cigarettes a day and drinks 2-3 cans of beer each night. Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 155/96 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 16/min. The patient's BMI is 35 kg/m2. He has clear lungs and normal first and second heart sounds. His abdomen is obese, nontender, and without hepatosplenomegaly. His fingers are shown in the images below. There is no joint tenderness and no joint effusions are present elsewhere. Serum creatinine level is normal and fasting blood glucose level is 133 mg/dL.
explanation:
This patient with metabolic syndrome has visible tophi over the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, characteristic of tophaceous gout. Tophi indicate chronic intraarticular uric acid deposition. For patients with frequent attacks of gouty arthritis, prophylaxis with allopurinol is the preferred long-term treatment.

(Choice B) Etanercept (TNF inhibitor) is for severe RA or psoriatic arthritis, not gout.

(Choices C and E) Methotrexate and sulfasalazine are DMARDs used for RA; RA typically spares the DIP joints.

(Choice D) Prednisone is used for acute polyarticular attacks of gout in patients who cannot tolerate NSAIDs, but it is not for long-term relief.

stem: A 35-year-old woman with no significant past medical history comes to the physician due to muscle and joint pains over her entire body for the past 6 months. She feels as if she has "the flu" all the time. The patient also experiences fatigue, mental slowness, and occasional headaches. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she has tenderness to gentle palpation over the muscles of her neck, shoulders, and back. There is no synovitis. Laboratory results show normal electrolytes, complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and thyroid function.
explanation:
Fibromyalgia (FM) commonly presents in young to middle-aged women with widespread pain, fatigue, and cognitive disturbances. Initial management includes patient education, regular aerobic exercise (cardiovascular fitness training), and good sleep hygiene. Although patients may have short-term pain after activity, regular exercise improves long-term pain.

(Choice B) Opioids such as hydrocodone likely do not outweigh the risks in FM and may actually worsen pain status.

(Choice C) Hydroxychloroquine is effective for SLE or RA, but not for FM.

(Choices D and E) Prednisone and Methotrexate are for inflammatory conditions (eg PMR, RA) which usually present with elevated ESR. FM is non-inflammatory.

stem:
A 55-year-old man comes to the office due to a 2-year history of pain in both hands with intermittent swelling of the finger joints. The pain impairs his functioning as a carpenter. He also has stiffness in the knees after prolonged sitting. Review of systems is negative for any other systemic or physical symptoms. His other medical problems include chronic bronchitis, impaired glucose tolerance, and a history of nephrolithiasis. His home medications include ibuprofen as needed, glucosamine/chondroitin supplements, and aspirin. His father died of cardiomyopathy at age 75. The patient does not use illicit drugs but smokes a pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 2 mixed alcoholic beverages every night. His vital signs are within normal limits. Finger nails appears pitted. There is boggy swelling and tenderness to palpation involving all the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 14.1 g/dL
Platelets: 320,000/mm3
Leukocytes: 7,800/mm3
Liver function studies
Bilirubin, total: 0.8 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 80 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 48 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 30 U/L
Immunologic and rheumatologic studies
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 25 mm/h
Rheumatoid factor: 10 U/mL
Cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies: negative

Chest x-ray reveals hyperinflation of the lungs but is otherwise normal. Hand x-ray is shown in the exhibit.
explanation:
Psoriatic arthritis can present with various clinical patterns including distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint arthritis, asymmetric oligoarthritis, symmetric polyarthritis (resembling rheumatoid arthritis), spondyloarthropathy, and aggressively destructive arthritis mutilans. Some patients may have a combination of patterns. Hand x-rays can reveal erosive changes with new bone formation, lysis of the terminal phalanges, joint destruction, "pencil-in-cup" appearance, and joint lysis with ankylosis. Most patients with psoriatic arthritis have had psoriasis for many years, but up to 30% of patients first develop arthritis followed by skin disease months to years later. In such cases, DIP joint arthritis and arthritis mutilans are considered the most specific for psoriatic arthritis. Nail changes such as pitting, yellowish discoloration, and onycholysis (lifting of the nail from the nail beds) also favor a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. This patient's hand x-ray reveals early "pencil-in-cup" appearance at the second and fifth proximal interphalangeal joints; this is consistent with psoriatic arthritis.

(Choice A) Hemochromatosis is associated with an arthritis that is similar to pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition) and typically affects the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. Hand x-rays usually reveal chondrocalcinosis and hook-like osteophytes involving the MCP joints.

(Choice B) Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy presents with digital clubbing and severe pain due to periostitis, and is often associated with intrathoracic malignancies (eg, lung cancer) or infectious diseases (eg, pulmonary infection). Radiographs of the long bones usually reveal periostitis instead of the destructive findings seen in this patient.

(Choice C) This patient's alcohol use and history of kidney stones should raise concern for the possibility of gout. However, gout usually presents as monoarthritis with x-rays revealing bony erosions and overhanging edges.

(Choice E) Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents as a symmetrical polyarthritis that commonly involves the MCP joints. This patient's nail pitting, normal inflammatory markers, and involvement of the DIP joints favor psoriatic arthritis.

stem:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician with 6 months of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea. She is unable to climb two flights of stairs without becoming short of breath. She also complains of dry cough, weight loss, and fatigue. She describes finger tingling and numbness when exposed to colder temperatures. Her past medical history is significant for acid reflux disease and diabetes mellitus. Her medications include metformin and omeprazole. She does not smoke cigarettes.

Her blood pressure is 155/80 mm Hg and her pulse is 86/min. Oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Small ulcers are seen at the fingertips bilaterally. Jugular venous pressure is estimated at 6 mm H2O. There are no heart murmurs. Inspiratory fine crackles are heard on auscultation at lung bases. There is no organomegaly.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 11.5 g/dL
WBC count: 5,600/mm3
Platelet count: 420,000/mm3
Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL

Chest x-ray shows bilateral reticular opacities.
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with likely systemic sclerosis (SSc), as summarized in the table. She has features of Raynaud's phenomenon, fingertip ulcers, abnormal chest x-ray, and acid reflux disease. Laboratory testing can usually confirm the diagnosis in clinically suspected patients. The most commonly seen antibodies include antitopoisomerase (SCL-70), anticentromere (ACA), and anti-RNA polymerase III. These antibodies also correlate with specific organ involvement (eg, lung, skin) and can sometimes correlate with prognosis.

(Choice A) Anticitrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP) are less common in SSc but more common in rheumatoid arthritis and overlap syndrome.

(Choice C) Antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are usually seen in primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC).

(Choice D) Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies are not associated with SSc but are more commonly associated with vasculitis.

(Choice E) Antisynthetase antibodies include anti-Jo-1 and are more specific for myositis. They are more commonly found in patients with dermatomyositis/polymyositis associated with interstitial lung disease. This patient has no muscle weakness.

stem:
A 68-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening pain and stiffness in her hands for the past several months. The patient initially had pain in the fingers and at the base of the thumb only after prolonged gardening or sewing, but she is now having difficulty with daily activities such as buttoning her blouse or holding her dog's leash. Her fingers are stiff in the morning, with gradual improvement after 15- 20 minutes of use. The patient has experienced no fever or swelling in the hands. She has attempted treatment of her pain with stretching exercises and over-the-counter acetaminophen without relief. Medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine and lisinopril. The patient occasionally drinks alcohol but does not use tobacco or illicit drugs.

Vital signs are within normal limits. Hand examination shows no redness, swelling, or joint deformities, but passive and active range of motion elicits pain at the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. The remainder of the examination is normal. X-ray of the patient's hand is shown in the exhibit.
explanation:
This patient has chronic noninflammatory arthritis in the hands. Her x-ray shows joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophyte formation in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of multiple digits, particularly the second and the third. These findings are consistent with osteoarthritis (OA). The initial management of OA is determined by the joints involved, severity of symptoms, and comorbid conditions. OA of the large weight-bearing joints (eg, knees) often improves with an exercise and weight loss program. Initial medication options include acetaminophen and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, systemic NSAIDs are associated with increased risk of complications in patients age ≥65 (such as this patient) and in those with comorbid hypertension, heart disease, chronic kidney disease, or a history of gastrointestinal hemorrhage (Choice A). For these patients, a topical NSAID (eg, diclofenac) may be equally effective and associated with less systemic toxicity.

(Choice B) The highest-quality studies on the use of glucosamine in OA have shown little benefit. It may have a small benefit in OA of the knee, but it is unlikely to be helpful for this patient.

(Choices C and D) Serologic testing (eg, cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies) is appropriate to screen for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and other autoimmune disorders, and prednisone is often used in short courses in RA to provide initial relief while planning appropriate long-term management. However, RA is characterized by prolonged morning stiffness, palpable synovitis, and sparing of the DIP joints. This patient's noninflammatory arthritis that prominently affects the DIP joints is more consistent with OA.

stem: A community-dwelling 80-year-old patient comes to the physician for preoperative assessment prior to elective hip replacement. Which of the following would be the best metric for determining the likelihood of 30-day post-operative complications and discharge to a nursing facility?
choice_b: Evaluation of pulmonary and kidney function
explanation:
Preoperative assessment of geriatric patients has proved challenging. While all of the above options can be helpful, recent studies indicate that the presence of frailty is strongly associated with adverse post-operative outcomes. A commonly used frailty index includes weight loss, exhaustion, physical weakness, slow walking speed, and decreased physical activity. Scoring is as follows: 4-5 points - frail, 2-3 points - intermediately frail, 0-1 points - non-frail. There is a progressive increase in length of stay and 30-day post-operative complications with an increasing number of points. Individuals classified as frail have an odds ratio of 20 when compared with non-frail patients for discharge to a nursing facility.

(Choices A and B) Determination of the likelihood of post-operative complications has traditionally been centered around the degree of dysfunction of key organ systems. These classification schemes still have value, but may be less useful in older patients.

(Choice D) Impaired cognitive function as determined by Mini-Mental Status Exam evaluation is associated with an increased risk of developing post-operative delirium. Impaired cognitive function is one of several important determinants of post-operative complications; however, it is best used in conjunction with additional assessment tools.

(Choice E) The medication list can often estimate the co-morbidity burden of a patient and, as such, is one of several factors that can be used to assess the likelihood of adverse post-operative outcomes.

A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because her fingers turn white episodically. The symptoms started 6 months ago during the summer when she noticed that opening the freezer or holding cold beverages precipitated these episodes. She was advised to avoid cold stimuli and wear protective gloves. However, the symptoms worsened during the winter and the episodes occurred more frequently. She feels numbness and pain with each episode and seeks relief. The patient has no skin thickening, chest pain, acid reflux symptoms, or shortness of breath. She has no other past medical history. She does not smoke but drinks alcohol occasionally. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits. The hand is shown in the picture.

Laboratory results are as follows:
WBC count: 4,500/mm3
Hemoglobin: 13.1 g/dL
Platelets: 240,000/mm3
Creatinine, serum: 0.9 mg/dL
Urine protein: None
Hepatitis B and C serologies: Negative
TSH, serum: 0.8 mIU/L
HIV ELISA: Negative
ANA, serum: 1:40, homogeneous pattern
explanation:
This patient's presentation is consistent with likely primary Raynaud's phenomenon (RP), an increased vascular response to cold temperature or emotional stress without an underlying cause. Primary RP usually occurs in women age <30 with symmetrical episodic attacks without evidence of peripheral vascular disease, tissue injury, or abnormal nailfold capillary examination. Laboratory studies (eg, ANA, ESR) are usually negative. Episodes can also involve tingling, numbness, and pain with skin color changes of pallor (white attack) or cyanotic (blue attack). Primary RP requires no further evaluation. Treatment primarily involves avoiding aggravating factors (eg. cold stimuli) as the risk of tissue-damaging digital ischemia is less likely with primary RP. Calcium channel blockers (eg, nifedipine, amlodipine) are the drugs of choice for continuing symptoms.

(Choice B) Aspirin combined with calcium channel blockers may be used in selected patients with severe secondary RP who are at risk for digital ulceration or larger-artery thrombotic events. However, aspirin alone will not alleviate symptoms.

(Choices C and D) Hydroxychloroquine and prednisone are used to treat SLE and RA, which can cause secondary RP. However, this patient's lack of systemic findings (eg, fever, joint pain, rash) makes these less likely.

(Choice E) Beta-blockers can actually worsen Raynaud's phenomenon and should be avoided in this patient.

A 78-year-old retired professor comes to the physician because of occasional headaches that have gradually worsened over the last six months. The headaches are right-sided and involve the corner of the right eye. He also gets pains in his jaw while chewing food. He has hyperlipidemia and he takes atorvastatin daily. He asks if the medication might be causing his symptoms. His other medical problems include coronary artery disease for which he had a stent placed in his left anterior descending artery five years ago. He has no history of strokes, vision problems, or peripheral artery disease. He is a lifetime non-smoker. Physical examination reveals a right-sided carotid bruit. Heart sounds are normal. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 10.9 g/dL
Platelets: 350,000 cells/μL
Creatinine: 0.7 mg/dL
Low density lipoprotein: 68 mg/dL
HemoglobinA1c: 4.8%
ESR: 82 mm/h
explanation:
This patient's presentation (i.e., jaw claudication, new headache, and increased ESR) is most consistent with giant cell arteritis (GCA). Jaw claudication is the most specific symptom and is seen in up to 50% of cases. Laboratory findings include elevated ESR, elevated C-reactive protein, and a normocytic normochromic anemia. Temporal artery biopsy confirms clinical diagnosis and treatment involves immediate glucocorticoid therapy. Since GCA affects primarily postmenopausal women and older men, steroids can predispose or worsen pre-existing osteoporosis. As a result, all patients should undergo bone mineral density measurements. Patients with GCA receiving steroids should also receive adjunctive calcium, vitamin D, and possibly bisphosphonates.

(Choice A) Although steroid therapy may predispose to ulcers, eradication of H. pylori does not significantly affect this.

(Choice B) Statin myopathy usually presents with proximal muscle myalgias/weakness (sometimes with elevated CK), but is usually not associated with jaw pain.

(Choice D) Screening for abdominal aortic aneurysms is less beneficial since they are much less common than ascending aortic aneurysms in GCA patients. It is recommended to perform yearly chest x-rays (up to ten years) to identify patients with thoracic aortic aneurysms prior to rupture or dissection.

(Choice E) Vitamin B12 deficiency usually causes a macrocytic anemia. However, GCA is usually associated with a normochromic normocytic anemia and reactive thrombocytosis that improves with steroids.

A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of aching and stiffness of her neck and shoulders for the past several weeks. This stiffness lasts for 1-2 hours after rising in the morning. She has tried ibuprofen without relief and has also experienced increasing fatigue for 4-6 weeks. She has no visual changes, headaches, other joint complaints, fever, or chills. Her weight is stable. The patient has osteoporosis, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, chlorthalidone, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and calcium and vitamin D supplements. On physical examination, she appears to be in no acute distress. Her temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), pulse is 84/min, blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 16/min. There is some limitation in range of motion of her shoulders and neck. There is no cervical muscle tenderness, no upper or lower extremity proximal muscle weakness, and no joint swelling or redness. 

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
Hematocrit: 33%
Platelets: 420,000/μL
Leukocytes: 9,800/μL
Serum chemistry panel
Sodium: 140 mEq/L
Potassium: 3.6 mEq/L
Chloride: 103 mEq/L
Bicarbonate: 24 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
Calcium: 9.6 mg/dL
Blood glucose: 188 mg/dL
HbA1C: 8.1%
Creatine kinase, serum: 57 U/L
TSH, serum: 8.0 μU/mL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), blood: 82 mm/h
explanation:
This patient, with pain and stiffness of proximal muscles associated with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), has typical features of polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). PMR is a disorder of unknown cause that occurs in approximately 1% of the population age >50. The ESR is >40 mm/h in 70%-90% of patients, and the C-reactive protein (CRP) is increased >10 mg/L in more than 90% of individuals. Administration of 15-20 mg/day of prednisone provides rapid resolution of symptoms; lack of a prompt response should call the diagnosis into question. Although there are no specific laboratory studies to confirm the diagnosis of PMR, age of onset, elevation of ESR, and rapid response to prednisone will differentiate PMR from other myopathies.

(Choice A) Diabetic amyotrophy typically presents as an acute asymmetrical pain followed by gradually worsening proximal lower extremity and back weakness, autonomic failure, and weight loss. This patient's lack of lower extremity weakness makes this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice B) Fibromyalgia presents with widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, stiffness, and aching with characteristic tender points. Fibromyalgia usually has a normal CRP and ESR.

(Choice C) Hypothyroid myopathy is characterized by myalgias, weakness, and elevated creatine kinase (CPK). This patient's mild elevation of TSH is more likely due to subclinical hypothyroidism, which is usually not associated with her degree of symptoms.

(Choice D) Statin myopathy is characterized by myalgias with proximal muscle weakness and elevated CPK. This patient has an elevated ESR with normal strength, which is more consistent with PMR.

A 38-year-old woman comes to the office for chronic aching pain and stiffness all over her body for the last 6 months. Her symptoms are worse with exercise. She also has experienced fatigue, headaches, and insomnia. The patient tried water aerobic exercise 3 times a week but had no symptom improvement. She has a history of irritable bowel syndrome. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple tender spots over bony prominences. Her muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities and deep-tendon reflexes are normal throughout. No sensory abnormalities are noted. There is no joint redness or swelling.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hematocrit: 43%
Leukocytes: 7,000/μL
Platelets: 200,000/μL
Creatine kinase, serum: 60 U/L
Thyroid-stimulating hormone: 3.0 μU/mL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 9 mm/h
explanation:
This patient's clinical features are consistent with fibromyalgia (FM). FM presents most commonly in young-to-middle-aged women with widespread pain, fatigue, and cognitive/mood disturbances. Initial FM treatment involves a multidisciplinary approach that includes patient education, regular aerobic exercise, and good sleep hygiene. Patients who do not respond to conservative measures may require medications. Tricyclic antidepressants (eg, amitriptyline) are preferred first-line drugs. Pregabalin, duloxetine, and milnacipran are alternate therapies approved for use in FM and can be useful for patients not responding to tricyclic antidepressants.

(Choice B) Pregabalin and gabapentin are anticonvulsant medications that have demonstrated effectiveness in FM. However, other anticonvulsants, including carbamazepine, are not known to be beneficial.

(Choices C and D) Colchicine is used for treating gout. Methotrexate can effectively treat inflammatory arthritides. Neither drug is effective for fibromyalgia.

(Choice E) Opioids (eg, oxycodone), with the exception of tramadol, are usually not recommended for fibromyalgia as there is little evidence that they provide significant relief, and the risks (abuse) outweigh the benefits.

A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician with complaints of weakness and skin rash. She thinks that her symptoms could be related to medications she started on over the last 6 months. She was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia and takes valsartan, amlodipine, chlorthalidone, and atorvastatin. It has become progressively more difficult for her to perform activities of daily living. She has no family history of skin disease. Her vital signs are normal. BMI is 33 kg/m2 Physical examination findings are shown in the pictures below. She has decreased muscle strength (4/5) in the quadriceps muscles bilaterally. Deep-tendon reflexes are 1+ and symmetrical. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 89 fL
Platelets: 150,000/μL
Leukocytes: 4,100/μL, normal differential
Serum chemistry
Blood urea nitrogen: 20 mg/dL
Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
Liver function studies
Total protein: 6.5 g/dL
Albumin: 4.0 g/dL
Alkaline phosphatase: 70 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 87 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 74 U/L
Creatine kinase, serum: 1286 U/L
Thyroid-stimulating hormone: 2.9 μU/mL
explanation:
This patient's cutaneous manifestations strongly suggest dermatomyositis (DM). Patients with DM usually present with symmetrical weakness that is more proximal. Classic skin findings include Gottron's papules, which are violaceous to dusky pink papules with scaling over the extensor surfaces of the MCP and IP hand joints and dorsal aspect of the wrists, elbows, and knees. Fewer than 50% of patients present with violaceous periorbital rash in the upper eyelid (heliotrope rash). Other skin findings include shawl sign (diffuse, flat erythema in a V-shaped distribution over the chest and shoulder), mechanic's hands, and erythroderma. Diagnosis is suggested by these clinical findings and can be confirmed with laboratory testing, EMG, and skin/muscle biopsy. Treatment involves glucocorticoids and evaluation for possible associated malignancy.

(Choice B) Statins can cause myalgias, acute rhabdomyolysis, and, rarely, inflammatory myopathy. Cutaneous manifestations are usually not present.

(Choice C) Psoriasis usually presents with scaly plaques on the extensor surfaces of the arms and does not normally cause muscle weakness.

(Choice D) Lupus may present with malar or discoid rash, myalgias, and arthritis. However, it does not usually cause muscle weakness.

(Choice E) Systemic sclerosis can present with sclerodactyly, inflammatory myositis, and fatigue. However, it usually does not present with the skin findings seen in this patient.

A 33-year-old woman comes in for a follow-up appointment. She was seen 6 months ago for a rash on her face, profound fatigue, and arthritis. The patient was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus and started on hydroxychloroquine and low-dose prednisone. She has experienced marked improvement in her symptoms and has resumed her usual activities. Physical examination shows a faint facial rash but is otherwise unremarkable.

Current laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 10.4 g/dL
Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
Urinalysis
White blood cells: 20-30/hpf
Red blood cells: many/hpf
24-hour urine protein: 900 mg/24 hr
Immunologic and rheumatologic studies
Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody: 5 IU/mL (<30.0 IU/mL)
Antinuclear antibody: strongly positive (negative)
choice_a: CT of the abdomen with contrast
explanation:
Over half of all patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) will develop renal disease during their lifetime, an important indicator of overall prognosis. A renal biopsy is needed to accurately distinguish among the various subtypes of LN. Renal biopsy should be performed when any new evidence of kidney involvement is present, including proteinuria (≥500 mg/day), elevated creatinine, or active urine sediment. Mild proteinuria alone does not require aggressive immunosuppressive therapy, and biopsy may not be necessary. Repeat biopsies should be performed with evidence of new or worsening laboratory markers as transformation of LN subtypes can occur.

(Choice A) Radiologic imaging has little role in the evaluation of LN, although renal ultrasonography and noncontrast CT scans can be used in acute kidney injury to rule out other suspected causes.

(Choices B and D) Hydroxychloroquine, with or without glucocorticoids, is appropriate for mild SLE without nephritis. However, additional immunosuppressive therapy is likely needed in this patient. The particular regimen is determined by the specific LN subtype, which is based on renal biopsy findings.

(Choice E) Urine protein electrophoresis may demonstrate polyclonal gammopathy in LN but would not be helpful in distinguishing the LN subtype.

A 32-year-old right-hand-dominant woman living in New Hampshire comes to the physician complaining of right wrist pain for the past 3 months. She has no history of tick bites, recent travel, or illness in the family. Review of systems is negative for fever, pain or swelling in any other joints, skin rash, or recent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections. The patient is sexually active in a monogamous relationship. She delivered her first child 4 months ago. She smokes marijuana occasionally.

Her temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 12/min. She weighs 80 kg (176 lb). There is a sharp tenderness on palpation of the radial styloid at the wrist. The pain is aggravated on ulnar deviation of the wrist after she is asked to make a fist over the thumb. There is no synovitis or tenderness noted on any other joints. The right hand x-ray is normal.
choice_e: Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint
explanation:
This patient's wrist pain, history of caring for an infant, positive Finkelstein's maneuver, and normal hand x-ray suggest de Quervain's tenosynovitis. Chronic overuse of the wrist, trauma, or repetitive activity may entrap the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons at the radial styloid process. The resultant tendinitis/tenosynovitis causes pain. The tenosynovitis occurs most commonly in women ages 30-50 with infants and daycare workers. Patients usually present with pain at the radial side of the wrist, pain can radiate to the thumb or volar aspect of the wrist with movement. Examination may show painful swelling or enlargement of the first extensor (dorsal) compartment. Tenderness and thickening at the radial styloid can be present in many patients. Finkelstein's maneuver involves grasping the patient's clenched hands (with fingers over the thumb) and rotating the wrist toward the ulnar aspect. Pain with movement is a positive sign and suggests the diagnosis. Acute treatment involves activity modification, thumb splints, and anti-inflammatory agents.

(Choice A) Carpal tunnel syndrome presents with pain or paresthesia in the distribution of the median nerve with a positive Tinel's sign.

(Choice C) Gonococcal arthritis usually presents with tenosynovitis, migratory polyarthritis, and pustular skin lesions.

(Choice D) Lyme arthritis typically presents with intermittent or persistent monoarthritis affecting larger joints and more swelling than pain.

(Choice E) X-ray is usually normal in de Quervain's tenosynovitis; CMC osteoarthritis may have subluxation, diminished space, osteophytes, and sclerosis.

A 75-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up of osteoporosis. She has been on weekly oral risedronate for the last 2 years and has an adequate daily intake of calcium and vitamin D via diet and oral supplements. However, in the past year the patient has experienced 2 vertebral compression fractures and lost 5.1 cm (2 in) in height. She was evaluated in a fall reduction program, and home safety improvements were implemented. A home health aide assists the patient with her medications and notes that adherence has been excellent. Medical history is notable for a mild stroke 2 years ago with minimal residual deficits. Vital signs are normal. BMI is 20 kg/m2. On examination, the patient appears frail and has a modest thoracic kyphosis. Physical examination is otherwise normal.

Laboratory results show normal blood counts, liver function tests, serum creatinine, alkaline phosphatase, TSH, serum parathyroid hormone, anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody assay, 25-hydroxyvitamin D, and serum protein electrophoresis. 24-hour urine calcium excretion is 290 mg. DXA reveals a T-score of -2.8 in the hip and -3.6 in the spine, which represents a significant (>5%) decrease compared with her last test 2 years ago.
explanation:
This patient has osteoporosis and has received appropriate first-line treatment with a bisphosphonate. However, she has experienced progressive bone loss while on treatment and has severe osteoporosis (T-score ≤-3.5 or T-score ≤-2.5 with a fragility fracture) and recurrent fragility fractures. Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone analog that is useful in patients with severe osteoporosis or who fail first-line treatment. It is given by daily subcutaneous injection and can increase bone density and reduce fracture risk. Treatment with teriparatide is typically prescribed for 2 years, after which a bisphosphonate is resumed to preserve gains in bone density. However, there is no evidence of reduced fracture risk with concurrent therapy (Choice B).

(Choice A) Raloxifene is less effective than bisphosphonates and has not been proven to reduce fractures in combination. It is not recommended for patients with increased thromboembolic risk (eg, prior stroke).

(Choice C) Hip protectors have not been shown to reduce the risk of hip fractures and are not recommended.

(Choice D) DXA confirms progressive bone loss, and an N-telopeptide assay would not improve management.

stem:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis comes to the physician with persistent hand pain aggravated by use. She was prescribed tramadol and occupational therapy 1 year ago and has had no relief. Rheumatoid arthritis was diagnosed 20 years ago, and she was started on methotrexate, prednisone, and hydroxychloroquine at that time. She was prescribed etanercept 10 years ago and switched to adalimumab 5 years later due to persistent disease activity. The patient's other medical problems include hypertension and acid reflux disease. Her current medications include methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, adalimumab, tramadol, prednisone, and ibuprofen. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Her vital signs are normal. Musculoskeletal examination is notable for the presence of rheumatoid deformities in the hands and feet. There is no joint tenderness or effusion. Neurological examination is within normal limits. 

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 12.0 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 84 fL
Platelets: 200,000/μL
Leukocytes: 4,800/μL
Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
Calcium: 9.4 mg/dL
Glucose: 120 mg/dL
C-reactive protein (CRP): 5 mg/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 18 mm/h
choice_a: Add infliximab to the current regimen
choice_b: Add sulfasalazine to the current regimen
choice_c: Prescribe a short course of high-dose prednisone
choice_e: Switch from oral to subcutaneous methotrexate
explanation:
This patient with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis (RA) has pain and functional limitations not explained by the inflammatory aspect of her disease. Her ESR and CRP are not elevated, and she has no joint effusions or tenderness. The pain is likely from mechanical stress of joint deformities and/or destruction. Due to failure of conservative treatment (eg, NSAIDs and occupational therapy), the next step would be orthopedic evaluation. Surgery is indicated in RA patients with joint destruction causing intractable pain, severe functional disability, or impending tendon rupture. Surgical options include total joint replacement, soft-tissue release, and joint fusion. Timely referral can prevent further joint destruction and allow for successful rehabilitation.

(Choice A) This patient's pain is likely mechanical from joint destruction rather than from inflammatory disease activity. Adding more aggressive biologic therapy with a TNF-α antagonist will likely not benefit her.

(Choices B, C, E) Adding another DMARD, increasing the dose of prednisone, or switching to subcutaneous methotrexate are options for patients with active disease and markers of inflammation. This patient would not benefit from these options.

stem:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician with 2 months of arm and leg weakness accompanied by puffy swelling of her hands. She also complains of dry eyes and mouth. She reports that her fingers turn blue or white when exposed to cold temperatures. The patient was evaluated for fatigue 6 months ago and was found to have normal complete blood count, serum chemistry, thyroid-stimulating hormone, vitamin D level, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein. Her antinuclear antibody test was positive at a low titer 1:80. She was advised to increase her aerobic activity level and was prescribed myofascial stretching exercises. She has no other significant past medical history. Her medications include acetaminophen and oral contraceptive pills. The patient drinks alcohol occasionally but does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. She works on a factory assembly line and has 3 children.

Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, she has several telangiectasias in the face. Both hands appear edematous and there is synovitis in several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. There is no leg edema. Muscle strength is decreased symmetrically and is 4/5 in both upper and lower extremities.

Laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 80 fL
Platelet count: 190,000/μL
Leukocyte count: 5,800/μL
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
Creatine kinase: 856 U/L
Thyroid-stimulating hormone: 3.5 μU/mL
explanation:
This patient's presentation of fatigue, muscle weakness, sicca symptoms (eg, dry eyes and mouth), Raynaud's phenomenon, and hand swelling (synovitis) is consistent with likely mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD). MCTD is an overlap syndrome associated with anti-U1-RNP (ribonucleoprotein) antibodies and features of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Diagnosis requires anti-RNP antibodies and the presence of swollen hands, myositis, synovitis, or Raynaud's phenomenon. Unlike in SLE, patients with U1-RNP antibodies rarely develop diffuse glomerulonephritis, psychosis, or seizures. However, they usually develop early Raynaud's phenomenon, sclerodactyly, inflammatory muscle disease, and pulmonary hypertension. Treatment is usually glucocorticoids.

(Choice A) Antibodies to aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases (eg, anti-Jo-1) are more specific for myositis. Her symptoms are more suggestive of a mixed disorder.

(Choice B) Antibodies to topoisomerase are associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Scleroderma does not usually cause the significant hand arthritis seen in this patient.

(Choice C) Anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are specific for SLE. This patient does not have characteristic lupus symptoms (eg, weight loss, alopecia, malar rash).

(Choice D) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) and microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) usually present with oronasal inflammation and abnormalities on urinalysis and/or chest imaging.

stem:
A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3 day history of pain and swelling in his left knee. He also reports nausea and feeling weak earlier today. He has a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and has had several previous episodes of "fluid in the knee." He currently takes methotrexate and sulfasalazine for his RA. Tumor necrosis factor inhibitor therapy was prescribed two years ago but was discontinued after six months due to frequent sinus infections and exacerbation of his congestive heart failure. His other medical problems include hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, colonic polyps, essential tremor, congestive heart failure, and a remote history of asbestos exposure. His other medications include furosemide, propranolol, lisinopril, aspirin, and simvastatin.

His temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 16/min. He has no jugular venous distention. His heart sounds are normal and his lungs are clear. Musculoskeletal examination is notable for extensive deformities in the hands due to long-standing arthritis. His right knee is normal. The left knee is tender and swollen and he is unable to extend it due to pain.

Joint aspiration yields 20 cc of synovial fluid. Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 11.9 g/dL
Platelets: 250,000 cells/µL
Leukocyte count: 9,500 cells/µL
Serum chemistry
Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L
Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
Immunologic and rheumatologic studies
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 25 mm/h
Uric acid, serum: 8.5 mg/dL
Synovial fluid analysis
Crystals: None
Gram stain: Negative
Total cell count: 65,000 cells/µL
White blood cells: 60,000 cells/µL
Neutrophils: 88%
Red blood cells: 2000 cells/µL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation: This patient's clinical presentation (e.g., sudden onset of knee joint swelling, nausea, weakness, and inability to move joint) and synovial fluid analysis (increased cell count with 88% neutrophils) are suspicious for a septic joint. Damaged joints (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis) serve as a nidus for infection and can predispose to septic arthritis. However, many rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients with septic arthritis do not present acutely and may not have fever, chills, or peripheral leukocytosis. This is particularly common in elderly patients, which often leads to a delayed diagnosis. Although RA alone can present as "pseudoseptic arthritis" with florid acute synovitis and marked synovial fluid leukocytosis, septic arthritis must be excluded first. Diagnosis is usually suggested by synovial fluid showing elevated leukocytes (50,000-150,000 cells/µL), positive Gram stain, and positive fluid culture. However, synovial fluid Gram stain can be negative in 20-30% of septic arthritis cases, especially with gram-negative bacteria. Blood cultures are positive in 50% of patients and must always be obtained prior to antibiotic therapy. Treatment consists of IV antibiotics and joint drainage. This patient should be monitored clinically and started on IV antibiotics until culture results return. (Choice A) Colchicine would be effective in treating gouty arthritis, but the lack of crystals in this patient's synovial fluid makes this diagnosis unlikely. (Choice B) Intraarticular steroid injection should not be performed until infection is excluded. Repeated steroid injections are an important risk factor for septic arthritis. (Choice D) Prednisone is effective in RA flare-up, but infectious arthritis should be excluded first. (Choice E) TNF antagonists may be used cautiously in class 1 and 2 congestive heart failure (CHF), but are contraindicated in class 3 and 4 CHF. Since the patient had CHF exacerbation with a TNF antagonist, it would be inappropriate to restart the medication. In addition, TNF antagonists are not useful in acute joint inflammation.

stem: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of bilateral groin pain that is worse on the right side than the left. The pain is aggravated by any type of prolonged weight bearing. He feels particularly stiff in the hips in the mornings and after sitting in one place for a few hours. He was prescribed physical therapy and tramadol 4 months ago. After some temporary relief, he now feels more pain throughout the day, which limits his daily activities. He also received physical therapy last year, which provided only temporary relief. He denies any pain or swelling in his other joints or systemic symptoms. His daughter who accompanies him states that he had recently complained of dizziness. His other medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, peripheral vascular disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. The patient lives at home by himself. His medications include aspirin, metformin, glipizide, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, acetaminophen, and tramadol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Range of motion of the spine is normal and without pain. There is no scoliosis or excessive kyphosis. There is significant reduction in internal and external rotation at the hip joints accompanied by pain. Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are unremarkable. ESR is 15 mm/hr. A radiograph of the right hip joint is shown here. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?
choice_a: Increase tramadol to the maximal tolerated dose
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with advanced noninflammatory osteoarthritis (OA) with severe pain that limits his activities of daily life. Hip OA patients typically present after age 50 with groin pain and impaired internal rotation (<15°) and hip flexion (<115°). Diagnosis also requires two of the following: ESR <20 mm/hr, x-rays showing osteophytes (femoral or acetabular), or joint space narrowing (superior, axial, or medial) on hip radiographs. This patient's x-ray shows a complete loss of joint space, osteophytes, and sclerosis of the acetabular articular surfaces and the head of the femur. Nonpharmacologic treatments (e.g., weight loss, wedged shoe insoles) are recommended first and are effective in some patients. Acetaminophen is recommended as a first-line therapy for noninflammatory OA followed by NSAIDs as needed in patients with persistent symptoms. The next step is to try intraarticular steroid injections followed by intraarticular hyaluronic acid or short-term opioids (e.g., oxycodone) in refractory patients. Patients with persistent symptoms and significant impairment (such as this patient) usually require total hip replacement. Surgery should be performed early before the patient develops significant deformities, joint instability, contractures, or muscular atrophy. (Choices A and C) Tramadol is preferred over NSAIDs in patients with renal impairment; however, it can cause dizziness and confusion. Since this patient already has dizziness, increasing the dose is not appropriate. In addition, adding an opioid can cause more dizziness and confusion in this elderly patient. (Choice B) Intraarticular hyaluronic acid products are approved for knee osteoarthritis, but are more useful in OA of recent onset rather than severe advanced OA. These products have been studied for use in other joints, but are not yet FDA approved. (Choice E) Oral corticosteroids are not beneficial in OA; they are more useful in polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). However, PMR usually presents with symmetric bilateral stiffness in the hips and shoulders as well as an elevated ESR.

A 69-year-old woman with a long history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is brought to the physician by her daughter because of gait instability and near-falls. She was previously able to walk outdoors with the use of a cane, but she has required a walker for the past three months. She also notes that her mother has been holding onto the furniture when she walks from room to room. The patient denies any new joint pain or discomfort, muscle pain, or numbness in her arms and legs. The patient had RA treatment in the past with methotrexate. She underwent right-sided knee replacement seven years ago. Recent x-rays of the replaced joints did not demonstrate any fractures or prosthesis loosening. Her other medical problems include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and lactose intolerance. Her current medications include low-dose prednisone, ibuprofen, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, calcium, and vitamin D.

Her blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg supine and 130/90 mm Hg standing. Her pulse is 85/min and regular. Joint examination shows subluxation of the metacarpophalangeal joints and ulnar deviation bilaterally. There is mild synovitis of both wrists. Flexion is moderately restricted at the right hip. The knees show full range of motion. Motor strength is 4/5 in the proximal muscles of both upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in both the upper and lower extremities bilaterally with a few beats of unsustained clonus at the ankles. Her gait is unsteady. She cannot walk heel-to-toe without assistance. Proprioception is decreased at both ankles. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
choice_b: Order an MRI of the cervical spine
choice_c: Refer to physical therapy for gait training
choice_e: Stop prednisone and re-evaluate in 2-4 weeks
explanation: This patient's presentation is most consistent with cervical myelopathy, likely due to atlanto-axial (C1-C2) subluxation from rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Risk factors for cervical subluxation include late-onset RA, elevated C-reactive protein, rapidly progressive peripheral joint disease, and early subluxation of peripheral joints. C1-C2 is the only spinal segment lined by a synovial membrane. Patients with RA can develop synovitis with erosions that destroy adjacent ligaments anchoring C1-C2, causing eventual subluxation of C1 relative to C2 (most often anteriorly). This creates pressure on the adjacent spinal cord and results in cervical myelopathy. Patients present with symptoms/signs listed in the above table. Plain radiographs are sometimes difficult to interpret but may show separation between C1 and C2. A spinal MRI is preferred to visualize the cervical spine for spinal cord compression, bony erosions, and synovitis. Patients with subluxation without signs of cord compression can be treated medically with neck collars and close monitoring with fall prevention. Patients with signs of cord compression usually require surgery for spinal stabilization. This patient is very symptomatic and should undergo cervical MRI. (Choice A) The serum CK and TSH would be elevated in thyroid myopathy, which usually presents with myalgias and diffuse muscle weakness rather than the gait and sensory findings seen in this patient. (Choice C) Physical therapy with gait training may be required in the future, but this patient first needs an MRI to evaluate for spinal cord disease. (Choice D) Anti-TNF therapy given early to RA patients may prevent future erosive joint disease and subluxations. However, this patient has chronic changes and would likely not benefit from this therapy at this time. (Choice E) Discontinuing prednisone in this patient will likely not help this patient since she has evidence of cervical disease that requires prompt imaging.

explanation: Early identification of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients with predictive factors for erosive disease can lead to more aggressive therapy with disease-modifying agents (Table). Positive anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (CCP) antibodies with high titers predict radiographic progression and poorer functional outcomes in RA (Choices A, D, and E). Patients with both positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies may benefit from more aggressive disease-modifying antirheumatic drug therapy compared to other patients (Choice B). In addition, elevated ESR and CRP may also predict RA disease activity with poorer outcomes.

stem: A 38-year-old Puerto Rican woman comes to the physician because of fever and fatigue for the last two weeks. Over the past few days, she has developed bilateral pedal edema, ankle pain with walking, and painful bruises on her shins without any trauma. She denies diarrhea, vaginal discharge, or lower abdominal pain. Her weight has been stable. She has no travel history within the past year. She denies tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. She is in a monogamous relationship with her long-standing, live-in boyfriend and uses oral contraceptives. Her temperature is 38.1 C (100.5 F), blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 86/min. Chest examination is unremarkable. The liver span is 11 cm and the tip of the spleen is not palpable. There are several violaceous, tender, raised lesions over both pretibial areas and 1+ pretibial edema. Both ankles are warm to the touch with some discomfort on passive movement. Complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and urinalysis are all within normal limits. Which of the following would be most useful in establishing the diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with Löfgren's syndrome, a variant of sarcoidosis. Löfgren's syndrome classically presents with the triad of hilar adenopathy, erythema nodosum, and acute polyarthritis. The arthritis typically involves both ankles (> 90% of cases) and other large joints in the lower extremities. Because the presentation is so classical, Löfgren's syndrome does not require a tissue biopsy and can be diagnosed based on clinical presentation alone. Patients with suspected Löfgren's syndrome usually require chest imaging (e.g., chest CT if chest x-ray is negative) to identify hilar adenopathy. This variant of sarcoidosis is usually self-limiting, with a favorable long-term prognosis. Although no controlled trials are available, NSAIDs usually offer symptomatic relief and corticosteroids are generally not utilized. (Choice B) HIV infection can present with systemic symptoms, as seen in this patient, but is not usually associated with ankle involvement and erythema nodosum. The rash in HIV is often generalized, maculopapular, and frequently involves the mucous membranes. (Choice C) Although rheumatoid arthritis may present with joint disease and fatigue, it is usually not associated with erythema nodosum. (Choice D) Tuberculosis may present with hilar adenopathy and erythema nodosum (very rare), but less commonly with ankle involvement. This patient should first undergo chest imaging to evaluate for hilar adenopathy before tuberculin skin testing, since her presentation is more consistent with Löfgren's syndrome. (Choice E) Disseminated gonococcal infections can present with either purulent monoarthritis or as a triad of skin rash, tenosynovitis, and polyarthralgia without purulent monoarthritis. Tenosynovitis is quite specific for gonococcal infection. The associated skin rash is usually pustular or vesiculopustular. Symmetric joint involvement is uncommon.

A 53-year-old seamstress comes to the physician with pain and intermittent swelling in her fingers for the past 3 years. Symptoms involve primarily the distal interphalangeal joints and occur after she sews. A year ago, she was hospitalized with upper gastrointestinal bleeding and was found to have erosive gastritis and a duodenal ulcer. Her other medical problems include hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and fatty liver. Her current medications are glipizide, sitagliptin, lisinopril, and amlodipine. Her blood pressure is 133/70 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. Her BMI is 26 kg/m². Her hands appear as shown below. There is bony swelling and tenderness of several distal interphalangeal joints. The remainder of the examination is within normal limits. Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin: 11.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume: 77 fL
Platelets: 320,000/µL
Leukocyte count: 5,200 cells/µL
Serum chemistry
Potassium: 4.2 mEq/L
Creatinine, serum: 1.8 mg/dL
Creatinine clearance: 40 mL/min

Liver function tests are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
explanation: This patient's presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis of the hands. She has a history of GI bleed and should avoid NSAIDs. A COX-2-specific NSAID (eg, celecoxib) may reduce the risk of GI bleed but has the same nephrotoxicity risk as a nonspecific NSAID. Since this patient has renal insufficiency, she should avoid all NSAIDs if possible (Choices C and E). Acetaminophen is the safest choice for this patient. Even in patients with advanced liver disease, tramadol and acetaminophen are safer than NSAIDs. (Choice B) Adalimumab (Humira), an anti-TNF antibody, is used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis or spondylarthritis. It is not indicated for the treatment of osteoarthritis. (Choice D) Methotrexate is indicated for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. However, the absence of pain or swelling of the PIP or MCP joints makes rheumatoid arthritis unlikely in this patient. Psoriatic arthritis is also treated with methotrexate. However, this patient's occupation and lack of skin findings make psoriasis unlikely.

stem: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing mid-back pain for the last 2 weeks. The pain has not improved with ibuprofen and acetaminophen combined with oxycodone. The pain limits her ambulation, dressing, and housekeeping. Her temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 14/min. Her back examination shows moderate tenderness in the mid-back along the vertebral column. She has an otherwise unremarkable examination. A lateral spine film reveals diffuse osteopenia with a vertebral compression fracture of T10. Blood for a complete blood count, metabolic panel, alkaline phosphatase, and 25-hydroxy vitamin D has been obtained. Which of the following is most likely to provide early pain relief in this patient?
explanation: This patient presents with a vertebral compression fracture, which is the most common type of osteoporotic fracture. Over 60% of osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures are clinically silent, but symptomatic patients can experience pain for 2-6 weeks or longer. The pain can radiate to the anterior abdomen and create a "girdle of pain." Many patients are successfully treated with an NSAID and acetaminophen, sometimes with an opioid. When pain persists, intranasal calcitonin is often effective. Although calcitonin is not a first-line agent to treat osteoporosis, intranasal calcitonin has been shown to significantly reduce pain from vertebral compression fractures. (Choice A) A variety of back braces are used for vertebral compression fractures, but clear-cut data demonstrating efficacy is lacking. Moreover, back braces can limit mobilization and promote disuse osteoporosis. (Choice B) Both intravenous and oral bisphosphonates are used for long-term treatment of osteoporosis and may provide pain relief over time. However, they are not effective for acute pain relief from vertebral compression fractures. (Choice C) Muscle relaxants are somewhat beneficial for nonspecific acute low back pain, but have not been demonstrated to be helpful in the management of vertebral compression fractures. (Choice E) While uncontrolled studies suggested that vertebroplasty is beneficial for symptomatic compression fractures, prospective controlled trials have failed to demonstrate efficacy. Vertebroplasty is invasive and associated with some risk due to cement leakage, including nerve injury and pulmonary embolization.

stem: A 35-year-old immigrant from Turkey comes to the physician for painful mouth ulcers that occur frequently and are accompanied by malaise and poor appetite. He was diagnosed with "canker sores" many years ago and has tried different oral rinse solutions. He also reports muscle aches and poor sleep. One year ago, he had anterior uveitis; laboratory studies at that time revealed no abnormalities. His other medical problems include acid reflux disease, constipation, and acne. The patient takes over-the-counter antacids and fiber supplements. He has a 15-pack-year smoking history but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. The patient's vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows 2 large ulcers on the buccal mucosa. There are papular and pustular skin lesions on the face. He has no joint swelling or deformities. He refuses laboratory work-up because each time blood is drawn he develops "skin bumps and infection." Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has recurrent painful oral ulcers, uveitis, acneiform skin lesions, and positive pathergy test, all features suggestive of Behçet's disease. Behçet's disease is an inflammatory disease more common in men from the "Silk Road" region (eastern Asia to the Mediterranean Sea). All patients have recurrent and painful oral ulcerations. About 75% have genital ulcerations and/or skin lesions (eg, acne and erythema nodosum). Genital ulcerations often leave scarring, which is rarely seen in any other condition. Some patients present very early with superficial or deep vein thrombosis. Although most symptoms of Behçet's disease are caused by vasculitis, the renal and peripheral nervous systems are not affected, as occurs in other vasculitides. There are no laboratory studies to diagnose Behçet's disease; it is diagnosed clinically based on symptoms and pathergy test (Table). Nonspecific inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP may be elevated. Treatment of Behçet's disease includes colchicine, glucocorticoids, or immunosuppressive agents. (Choice B) Patients with familial Mediterranean fever typically present with paroxysmal episodes of fever and concomitant serositis (peritonitis, pleuritis, or pericarditis). This patient does not have a fever or complaints of abdominal pain, making familial Mediterranean fever less likely. (Choice C) Herpes simplex infection can cause recurrent oral ulcers, keratitis, and, sometimes, uveitis. However, this patient's skin lesions and positive pathergy test are not consistent with herpes infection. (Choice D) Sarcoidosis involves the lungs in > 90% of patients and can present with uveitis, joint pain, and skin lesions (eg, erythema nodosum). However, painful mucocutaneous lesions and normal chest x-ray are not common with sarcoidosis. (Choice E) Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus can present with oral ulcers; however, these are usually painless. Behçet's disease is most likely given the positive pathergy test.

stem: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of joint pain. He has had 2 years of intermittent and mild arthralgias of his hands, wrists, and shoulders at night. He recently developed pain in his wrists and hand pain with flexion mainly at the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints. He has no morning stiffness or warmth or redness around his joints. There is no history of fever, weight loss, or subcutaneous nodules. His medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago and hypertension and hyperlipidemia diagnosed 3 years ago. Mild liver function abnormalities were detected and attributed to possible fatty liver 2 years ago. His medications include metformin, lisinopril, and rosuvastatin. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. BMI is 34 kg/m². There is swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally. He has no synovial swelling or abnormalities of his proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. There are no abnormalities of the wrists, shoulders, or hips. X-rays of the hands and wrists reveal narrowing of the third, fourth, and fifth metacarpophalangeal joints with hook-shaped osteophytes at the metacarpal heads. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 15 mm/hr. Which of the following would most likely show the cause of this patient's current symptoms?
choice_c: Rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies
explanation: This patient's diabetes mellitus, atypical degenerative joint disease, and history of liver function abnormalities suggest likely hemochromatosis. Differentiating idiopathic primary osteoarthritis from secondary forms of osteoarthritis can be difficult. Secondary causes of osteoarthritis include trauma, underlying inflammatory arthritis, infection, calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, and metabolic disorders (eg, hemochromatosis). Primary osteoarthritis of the hands most commonly involves the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints and the first metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint. This patient's narrowing of the third, fourth, and fifth MCP joints and the findings of hook-shaped osteophytes strongly suggest hemachromatosis as the cause of the arthritis. Secondary osteoarthritis occurs in 40-60% of patients with hemochromatosis and can present with arthralgias, hand involvement (eg, wrist), and shoulder pain (see table). Screening this patient for hemochromatosis initially with serum transferrin saturation is the next appropriate step, as high levels correlate with arthritis. (Choice A) Rosuvastatin may cause mild liver abnormalities and myalgias in the proximal muscles but typically does not cause hand arthritis, as seen in this patient. (Choice B) HLA-B27 is linked to spondyloarthropathies (eg, ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis). However, this patient does not have other clinical features (eg, back pain, inflammatory eye disease, enthesitis, sausage digits) seen in many spondyloarthropathies. (Choice C) Although hemochromatosis can sometimes mimic rheumatoid arthritis (RA), this patient does not have other clinical features (eg, morning stiffness, subcutaneous nodules) of RA. In addition, the low sedimentation rate makes this less likely. (Choice E) Chronic tophaceous gout typically results in bone erosions with characteristic thin "overhanging" edges.
